تبریسی ، *مجسما البیان *میں ، فرشتوں کے اپنے آپ کو اجنبی کی حیثیت سے پیش کرنے کے انتخاب کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں ، اور بیک وقت اپنی پیشن گوئی کی بصیرت کو شامل کرتے ہوئے ابراہیم کی مشہور مہمان نوازی کی جانچ کرتے ہیں۔ "سلیم" کا سلام محض ایک معاشرتی بشکریہ کے طور پر نہیں بلکہ روحانی اشارے کے طور پر کام کرتا ہے ، شیعہ کو سمجھنے کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتا ہے کہ خدائی پیغامات اکثر صرف روحانی طور پر پاک ہونے کے لئے قابل رسائی معنی کی تہوں میں پردہ پاتے ہیں۔ لہذا ، ابراہیم کا ردعمل * تقوا * (خدا کے شعور) کی پیشن گوئی کی خوبی کو مجسم بناتا ہے ، جس میں اس کی احتیاط دنیاوی اضطراب کی بجائے خدائی ارادے کے لئے عقیدت سے پیدا ہوتی ہے۔  

مذہبی طور پر ، شیعہ تبصرے اس واقعہ کو * اسماح * (پیشن گوئی کی عدم استحکام) کے نظریے سے جوڑتے ہیں ، اور ابراہیم کے رد عمل کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں کہ اس کی الہی مرضی کے بارے میں ان کی غیر متزلزل پیشرفت کا ایک مظہر ہے ، یہاں تک کہ غیر یقینی صورتحال کے باوجود۔ مہمانوں کو کھانا پیش کرنے کا ان کے بعد کے عمل - اپنی پریشانی کے باوجود - اسلامی فقہ میں شامل ایک اصول ، مقدس مہمان نوازی کے ساتھ روحانی چوکسی کے انضمام کی مثال دیتا ہے۔ اس طرح یہ بیانیہ مومنین کے لئے ایک مثال بن جاتا ہے ، اور یہ واضح کرتا ہے کہ کس طرح خدائی رہنمائی دونوں واضح آزمائشوں اور لطیف علامات کے ذریعہ کام کرتی ہے ، جو الہی مقرر کردہ رہنماؤں کی حکمت کے ذریعہ ثالثی کی جاتی ہے۔ یہ ایک تصور میں مزید ایک تصور میں افل البیت کے آنٹولوجیکل کردار کے ذریعے پیشن گوئی کی لیگیسی کے وراثت اور ترجمان کی حیثیت سے بہتر ہے۔
52.layer3_urdu:
سورہ الہجر (15:52) میں ، حضرت ابراہیم کے اپنے فرشتہ مہمانوں کے بارے میں ابتدائی خدشات- * سلام * (امن) کے ان کے سلام کے باوجود ، "دوسرے" کے خوف کو نیویگیٹ کرنے کا ایک گہرا سبق دیتے ہیں ، ایک موضوع ہماری باہم مربوط ابھی تک پولرائزڈ دنیا سے شدید طور پر متعلقہ ہے۔ عصر حاضر کے شیعہ اسکالرز ، جیسے آیت اللہ سید الحیداری ، یہاں ابراہیم کی انسانیت کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں: اس کی وارنٹی فطری احتیاط کی عکاسی کرتی ہے ، پھر بھی اس کے حتمی کشادگی کے نمونے بات چیت کے ذریعے خوف کو کس طرح عبور کرسکتے ہیں۔ جدید اخلاقی فریم ورک میں ہمدردی کو ترجیح دیتے ہوئے یہ دوہری-خطرے سے دوچار ہے جو بنیاد پرست مہمان نوازی کے ساتھ خود کی حفاظت کو متوازن کرتے ہیں۔

نفسیاتی طور پر ، آیت ہمارے نیورو بائیوولوجیکل "فائٹ یا فلائٹ" کو سمجھے جانے والے خطرات کے ردعمل کی آئینہ دار کرتی ہے ، جو بقا کا ایک طریقہ کار اکثر آج کل ثقافتی یا نظریاتی اختلافات کی وجہ سے متحرک ہوتا ہے۔ پھر بھی نیورو سائنس نے یہ بھی انکشاف کیا ہے کہ ہمدردی اور تجسس ان بنیادی رد عمل کو دوبارہ پیش کرسکتا ہے ، جس سے امام علی کی اس تعلیم کے ساتھ صف بندی کی جاسکتی ہے کہ "علم خوف کو ختم کرتا ہے۔" معاشرتی طور پر ، ابراہیم کی کہانی زینوفوبیا اور قبائلی ازم پر تنقید کرتی ہے جیسے بحرانوں کو اینٹی ریفیوج بیانات یا اسلامو فوبک پالیسیوں جیسے بحرانوں کو فروغ دیتا ہے۔ اس کے مہمانوں کا ’پرامن ارادہ - نامعلوم شکلوں کے نیچے چھڑا ہوا ہے - معاشروں کو تعصبات پر سوال اٹھانے اور سطح کے اختلافات کے نیچے مشترکہ انسانیت کے حصول کے لئے انکوائری کرنے والے معاشروں کو۔

انٹرفیتھ کے متوازی بہت سارے: ابراہیمک روایات عالمی سطح پر مہمان نوازی کرتے ہیں ، یہودی * ہچناسات آرکیم * (مہمانوں کا خیرمقدم) سے لے کر اجنبیوں کے عیسائی تمثیلوں تک اجنبیوں کے بھیس میں۔ کثیر الثقافتی سیاق و سباق میں ، اس آیت میں مذہبی ، نسلی ، یا سیاسی چاہے وہ تقسیم کے پار فعال مشغولیت پر زور دیتا ہے۔ ماحولیاتی اخلاقیات کے اسکالرز جیسے ڈاکٹر سیئڈ حسین نصر اس طرح کی مہمان نوازی کو ماحولیاتی ذمہ داری سے مربوط کرتے ہیں۔

آج ، جیسے ہی آب و ہوا کی نقل مکانی سے لے کر ڈیجیٹل بیگانگی تک بحران عدم اعتماد کو بڑھاوا دیتے ہیں ، ابراہیم کا خوف سے اعتماد کا سفر ایک بلیو پرنٹ پیش کرتا ہے۔ جدید شیعہ مذہبی ماہرین پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ * سلام * غیر فعال امن نہیں بلکہ فعال امن سازی ہے - ذاتی عاجزی کی پرورش کرتے ہوئے نظامی عدم مساوات کو پامال کرنا۔ چونکہ فرشتوں کے پیغام نے بالآخر الہی رحمت کو لایا ، ہمارے دور میں ہمت کے ساتھ غیر یقینی صورتحال کو قبول کرنے ، حفاظت کو فضل میں تبدیل کرنے کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے۔

اس لمحے جب حضرت ابراہیم (علی ع الس السلام) کا مقابلہ "سلام" کے سلام میں آنے والے خدائی سفیروں کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے لیکن اس کے باوجود پاک خوف کے ساتھ جواب دیتا ہے کہ اہل بیت (علیہم السلام) کے ذریعہ روشن روحانی رازوں کی نقاب کشائی کرتی ہے۔ امام علی (عالیہ السلام) *ناہج البالاگھا *میں پڑھاتے ہیں: "حقیقی امن حقائق کی حقیقت کو پہچاننے کا پھل ہے۔" یہاں ، ابراہیم کا خدشہ فرشتوں کے عدم اعتماد سے نہیں بلکہ ان کے مرسل کی عظمت سے پہلے اس کے خوف سے پیدا ہوتا ہے۔ اماموں نے اس بات پر زور دیا کہ ہر الہی تصادم عقیدت اور تیاری دونوں کا مطالبہ کرتا ہے۔ اللہ کی لامحدود موجودگی سے پہلے روحانی تڑپ اور عاجزی کے مابین ایک توازن۔  

چھٹا امام ، جافر السادق (علیہ السلام) ، اس آیت پر تبصرے: "اللہ کے دوست ہمیشہ محتاط رہتے ہیں ، کیونکہ ان کے دل پالش آئینے ہیں جو اس کی عظمت کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔" ابراہیم کا خوف دنیاوی اضطراب نہیں ہے بلکہ *خواجہ *allah اللہ کے غلبے کے مباشرت علم سے پیدا ہونے والی حیرت زدہ حیرت ہے۔ یہ پاک * اولیہ * (سنتوں) کی حالت کا آئینہ دار ہے جو شیعہ الہیات کے مطابق ، * ولیہ * (خدائی سرپرستی) کو مجسم بناتا ہے۔ ان کی روحوں کو دوسروں کے ذریعہ غیبوں کو نظر آتا ہے ، بالکل اسی طرح جیسے ابراہیم نے اپنے مہمانوں کی آسمانی نوعیت کو ان کی انسانی آڑ کے نیچے سمجھا۔  

لیڈی فاطمہ (علیہا السلام) اپنی سرگوشی کی دعاوں میں پڑھاتی ہیں: "اے اللہ ، میرے خوف کو اپنی ناراضگی کے خلاف ایک قلعہ بنائیں ، اور میری امید آپ کے رحم و کرم پر ایک پل ہے۔" یہ دوہری ابراہیم کے ردعمل میں گونجتی ہے۔ احلول بائٹ مومنین کو دونوں ریاستوں کی کاشت کرنے کے لئے رہنمائی کرتے ہیں: خوف ہے کہ وہ گناہ سے باز آجائے گا ، اور امید کرتا ہے کہ عبادت میں استقامت کو ایندھن دیتا ہے۔  

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت ہمیں * تقوا * (خدا کے شعور) کے ساتھ الہی نعمتوں سے رجوع کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔ جب امن اترتا ہے - دعا ، قرآنی تلاوت ، یا خیراتی اداروں کے ذریعہ - ہمیں اسے لازمی طور پر نہیں بلکہ بحالی کے ساتھ وصول کرنا چاہئے ، ہر فضل کو جاننا شکرگزار کا امتحان ہے۔ امام زین العبدین (علیہ السلام) نے *ساہفا سججدیہ *میں مشورہ دیا ہے: "آپ کی روح اللہ کے حامیوں کے وزن پر کانپ اٹھے ، ایسا نہ ہو کہ آپ ان لوگوں کی راہ پر گامزن ہوں جنہوں نے نعمتیں حاصل کیں۔"  

اس طرح ، ابراہیم کا مقدس خوف کا لمحہ ایک روڈ میپ بن جاتا ہے: اماموں کی تعلیمات کی عینک سے روحانی مقابلوں کی تلاش کریں ، یاد کو یاد (*دھکر*) اور خود بخود (*محسابا*) کے ذریعے پاک کریں ، اور الہٰی*والیہ*کی پہچان میں ہر تجربے کو لنگر انداز کرتے ہیں۔
52.layer5:
Both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur on the narrative context of this verse, which describes Prophet Abraham’s encounter with angelic guests in human form. Scholars such as Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia) note that Abraham’s initial fear (*wajl*) arose from the strangers’ unusual refusal to partake in his hospitality—a cultural norm signaling either danger or divine purpose. Ibn Kathir and Al-Qummi similarly highlight Abraham’s swift transition from apprehension to reassurance upon recognizing their celestial identity, underscoring his exemplary trust in God.  

Divergences emerge in interpreting Abraham’s psychological state and the nature of his recognition. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi and Razi emphasize Abraham’s human caution, framing his fear as a natural response to unfamiliar visitors, later dispelled by divine reassurance. This aligns with Sunni theological emphasis on prophets’ humanity and their experiential wisdom. In contrast, Shia scholars such as Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) posit that Abraham’s fear stemmed from an immediate, intuitive awareness of their angelic mission, reflecting the Shia belief in prophetic and Imamic access to transcendent knowledge (*‘irfan*). Al-Qummi further suggests this episode prefigures the spiritual vigilance required to recognize divine guides, a theme central to Shia teachings on the Imamate.  

These interpretive differences reflect distinct theological frameworks. Sunni exegesis often prioritizes literal-historical analysis, while Shia tafsir incorporates esoteric layers (*batin*) tied to the Ahlul Bayt’s authority. Such nuances subtly influence devotional practices: Sunni readings may reinforce ethical hospitality, whereas Shia interpretations might emphasize discerning divine signs through spiritual heirs of the Prophet.  

Historically, these divergences arose from early Islamic scholarly traditions, with Shia exegesis evolving alongside doctrines of Imamah and Sunni scholarship consolidating within frameworks of textual and rational analysis. Despite these variations, both traditions unite in celebrating Abraham’s piety and the Quran’s moral depth, demonstrating shared reverence for prophetic exemplars.

53.layer1:
This verse from Surah Al-Hijr captures the moment when angels visited Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) to deliver joyous news after he initially felt unease at their unexpected arrival. The angels’ reassuring words, *"La tawjal"* ("Fear not"), immediately calm Ibrahim’s heart, illustrating Allah’s compassion toward His prophets even in moments of human uncertainty. Their message—*"nubashshiruka bi-ghulam alim"* ("we give you good tidings of a learned boy")—announces the birth of a son endowed with profound knowledge. While earlier Quranic accounts mention Ibrahim’s son Ishaq (Isaac), classical scholars note this verse also symbolically foreshadows the lineage of prophets and the *Ahlul Bayt* (Household of the Prophet), emphasizing Allah’s promise to bless righteous families with both spiritual and intellectual guidance.

The term *ghulam* (boy) signifies youth but is paired with *alim* (learned), highlighting that true knowledge transcends age—a theme central to Islam’s reverence for wisdom. The angels’ choice of *tubashshiruka* ("we give you good tidings") derives from *bishara* (glad tidings), indicating prophethood’s continuity and divine plans unfolding through generations. Historically, this moment reassures believers that Allah’s promises manifest even when circumstances seem unclear, as Ibrahim’s initial apprehension turns to joy through trust in divine wisdom.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on nurturing knowledge as a sacred duty. Just as Ibrahim’s son was destined for learning, parents are reminded to cultivate both religious and worldly education in their children, fostering curiosity and piety. The angels’ reassurance also serves as a metaphor for facing life’s uncertainties with faith: moments of doubt can precede blessings, and trust in Allah’s timing unlocks inner peace. By valuing wisdom and embracing patience, Muslims honor this timeless lesson—that knowledge and divine grace illuminate the path forward.
53.layer2:
In *Surah al-Hijr* (15:53), the divine emissaries reassure Prophet Ibrahim (AS) with the glad tidings of a “learned boy” (*ghulam alim*), a verse rich in theological and hermeneutical significance within Shia exegesis. Classical commentators such as Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize two primary dimensions: the identity of the promised son and the nature of his divinely ordained knowledge. While Sunni exegetes often associate this verse with the birth of Isaac (Ishaq), Shia traditions, drawing upon narrations from the Ahl al-Bayt (AS), frequently interpret it as referring to Ishmael (Ismail), the progenitor of the Arab line culminating in the Prophet Muhammad (SAWA) and the Imams (AS). This distinction underscores the Shia theological emphasis on the continuity of divine guidance through specific hereditary lines, a principle foundational to the doctrine of Imamate.

The descriptor *alim* (learned) is interpreted not merely as intellectual aptitude but as a manifestation of *‘ilm ladunni* (knowledge from the divine presence), a charisma bestowed upon prophets and their purified successors. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, elaborates that this knowledge transcends acquired learning, symbolizing innate wisdom granted by Allah’s grace—a concept aligning with the Shia belief in the infallibility (*ismah*) and preordained spiritual excellence (*ta’yid*) of divine guides. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (AS), as cited in classical sources, elucidates that such knowledge enables its bearer to perceive divine truths beyond ordinary human comprehension, a capacity integral to their role as intermediaries of celestial guidance.

Theological implications extend to the interplay between divine decree (*qadar*) and human agency. The angels’ reassurance (*la tawjal*) addresses Ibrahim’s momentary anxiety, illustrating the prophetic state of *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) amid divine trials. Tabatabai notes that Ibrahim’s reaction exemplifies the equilibrium between human emotional vulnerability and unshakable faith—a dynamic later reflected in the lives of the Imams, particularly during existential crises such as Karbala. Furthermore, the verse subtly reinforces the Shia juridical principle that true knowledge—whether prophetic, Imamic, or juristic—derives from divine appointment (*nass*) rather than human contrivance, shaping the Shia approach to religious authority (*marja’iyyah*).

In summation, this verse encapsulates core Shia doctrines: the hereditary transmission of divine authority, the ontological distinction of divinely guided figures, and the inseparability of knowledge from spiritual purification—a triad sustaining the Shia worldview across theology, jurisprudence, and spirituality.
53.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr, the angels’ reassurance to Prophet Ibrahim—"Fear not. We give you good tidings of a learned boy"—resonates deeply in modern Shia thought as a testament to divine wisdom intertwining knowledge with human potential. Contemporary scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi emphasize that this verse transcends its historical moment, symbolizing God’s commitment to nurturing *‘ilm* (knowledge) as a transformative force. Shirazi notes how Ibrahim’s story—receiving a child in old age—mirrors humanity’s capacity to birth intellectual and spiritual breakthroughs against seemingly insurmountable odds, a theme echoed in scientific fields where late-career researchers pioneer discoveries.  

The phrase *“learned boy”* (ghulam alim) invites reflection on the interplay of youth and wisdom. Scholar Sayyid Kamal Haydari frames this as a call to empower young generations ethically, urging societies to prioritize education systems that cultivate critical thinking alongside moral grounding. In an era where information overload often eclipses true understanding, this verse challenges us to redefine learning as holistic growth—embracing STEM fields but also empathy, environmental stewardship, and social justice.  

Globally, the verse speaks to crises like educational inequity. Over 250 million children lack basic schooling (UNICEF 2023), a disparity Shia theologians connect to the Qur’anic imperative of universal access to knowledge. Dr. Liyakat Takim, a contemporary Shia academic, links this to interfaith solidarity, noting how Abrahamic traditions share reverence for enlightenment—Judaism’s *talmud Torah*, Christianity’s “light of the world,” and Islam’s *noor* (divine light).  

Philosophically, the verse’s reassurance—“Fear not”—resonates in a climate-anxious world. Just as Ibrahim’s trust in divine promise overcame existential fear, modern resilience requires faith in collective agency. The “learned boy” becomes a metaphor for hope: every child, regardless of nationality or creed, carries potential to contribute solutions to crises like AI ethics or pandemics. In multicultural societies, this invites policies valuing diverse epistemologies—traditional wisdom alongside innovation—to build inclusive futures.
53.layer4:
The angels' declaration to Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) in this luminous verse carries profound echoes of the divine covenant manifested through the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). When the angels proclaim, *"We give you good tidings of a learned boy,"* they unveil a timeless truth: Allah’s chosen guides are endowed with *‘ilm ladunni* (knowledge from the Divine Presence), a celestial inheritance that flows through the purified lineage of prophethood and Imāmah. The "learned boy" here is not merely a reference to Prophet Ishaq (peace be upon him), but a spiritual foreshadowing of the infallible Imams, whose knowledge transcends the limits of mortal learning. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, *"We are the gates of the city of knowledge, and the Prophet is its door. Whoever seeks the city must enter through its door"* (Bihar al-Anwar).  

The Ahlul Bayt teach that true knowledge is a divine light (*nūr*) implanted in purified hearts. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains, *"Knowledge is not measured by much narration, but by the light of guidance placed in the heart"* (Al-Kafi). This aligns with the verse’s emphasis on *‘alīm* (learned) — not merely one who accumulates facts, but one whose soul is illuminated by Allah’s wisdom. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) embodies this truth, declaring, *"The heart is the vessel of divine revelation; purify it, and knowledge will flow into it like rivers."*  

For spiritual seekers, this verse invites reflection on the necessity of *wilayah* (divine guardianship) as the path to enlightenment. Just as Ibrahim’s son was destined for divine service, the Imams are the inheritors of prophetic wisdom, guiding humanity through the darkness of ignorance. Practical devotion to them — through studying their teachings, emulating their ethics, and seeking their intercession — becomes a means to internalize this heavenly knowledge.  

Imam Ali Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) advises in the *Sahifa Sajjadiyya*: *"Attach your heart to the rope of obedience to the Guides, for they are the lamps in the darkness of confusion."* To cultivate this connection, believers must cleanse their hearts through sincere prayer, Quranic reflection, and ethical rigor, recognizing that every atom of true understanding flows from the luminous chain of the Ahlul Bayt. In their teachings lies the map to transcend fear, as the angels counseled Ibrahim, and to walk the path of certainty (*yaqīn*)

مذہبی مضمرات خدائی فرمان (*قادر*) اور انسانی ایجنسی کے مابین باہمی مداخلت تک پھیلتے ہیں۔ فرشتوں کی یقین دہانی (*لا تواجل*) ابراہیم کی لمحہ بہ لمحہ اضطراب کو حل کرتی ہے ، جو الہی آزمائشوں کے درمیان*توقکول*(اللہ پر اعتماد) کی پیشن گوئی کی حالت کو ظاہر کرتی ہے۔ تبتابائی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ ابراہیم کا رد عمل انسانی جذباتی کمزوری اور غیر متزلزل عقیدے کے مابین توازن کی مثال دیتا ہے۔ یہ ایک متحرک بعد میں اماموں کی زندگیوں میں ظاہر ہوتا ہے ، خاص طور پر کربلا جیسے وجودی بحرانوں کے دوران۔ مزید برآں ، یہ آیت شیعہ فقہی اصول کو پوری طرح تقویت دیتی ہے کہ حقیقی علم - چاہے پیشن گوئی ، امامک ، یا فقیہ - الہی تقرری (*ناس*) سے انسانی تضاد کی بجائے ڈیورائیو ، مذہبی اتھارٹی (*مارجیہ*) کے لئے شیعہ نقطہ نظر کو تشکیل دیتے ہیں۔

خلاصہ یہ کہ یہ آیت شیعہ کے بنیادی عقائد کو شامل کرتی ہے: الہی اتھارٹی کی موروثی ترسیل ، خدائی ہدایت یافتہ شخصیات کا اونٹولوجیکل امتیاز ، اور روحانی تزکیہ سے علم کی لازم و ملزوم - جو مذہبی ، فقہ ، اور روحانیت کے پار شیعہ کے عالمی نظریہ کو برقرار رکھنے کا ایک سہ رخی ہے۔

53.layer5:
Both Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions converge in identifying the "learned boy" (*ghulam alim*) in this verse as a reference to Prophet Ishaq (Isaac), emphasizing his divinely bestowed knowledge and role within Abrahamic prophethood. Classical Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir contextualize the angels’ announcement as a fulfillment of Allah’s promise to Ibrahim (Abraham) and Sarah, underscoring the miraculous nature of Ishaq’s birth to aged parents. Qurtubi and Razi highlight the term *alim* (learned) as indicative of prophetic wisdom, with Razi noting its alignment with Ishaq’s later role in guiding his community. Similarly, Shia scholars such as Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) affirm this narrative but expand the theological implications, linking Ishaq’s knowledge to the broader concept of *‘ilm ladunni* (divinely inspired knowledge) inherited by the Ahlul Bayt.  

A key divergence arises in the scope of interpretation. Sunni exegesis typically confines the verse’s application to Ishaq’s prophethood, as seen in Ibn Kathir’s emphasis on its historical immediacy. In contrast, Shia commentaries like Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* and Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi* often extend the verse’s symbolism to the Imams, interpreting *alim* as a marker of the infallible knowledge vested in divinely appointed leaders. This reflects the Shia theological principle of Imamah, wherein hereditary spiritual authority complements prophethood.  

These differences stem from distinct hermeneutical frameworks. Sunni tafsir prioritizes the verse’s literal and historical context, while Shia scholarship frequently incorporates hadiths from the Imams to derive layered meanings. Such interpretations influence religious practice by shaping communal reverence for prophetic lineages—central to Shia spirituality—and reinforcing Sunni emphasis on prophetic continuity within Quranic narratives. Historically, these divergences emerged from early theological debates on leadership and knowledge transmission after the Prophet Muhammad, with each tradition developing its exegetical priorities within broader doctrinal frameworks. Both approaches, however, share a reverence for divine wisdom as a unifying theme.

54.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr, verse 54, Prophet Ibrahim (AS) responds to the angels who appeared to him in human form and delivered the miraculous news of a son despite his and his wife Sarah’s advanced age. His reply—*“abashartumuni ala an massaniya al-kibar, fabima tubashshirun”*—captures a moment of human astonishment intertwined with profound faith. The Arabic term *abashartumuni* (أَبَشَّرْتُمُونِى) comes from *bashara*, meaning “glad tidings,” often linked to divine promises. *Al-kibar* (ٱلْكِبَرُ) refers to the frailty and limitations of old age. Ibrahim’s question reflects natural human wonder—not doubt in Allah’s power but awe at how the impossible becomes possible through divine will.  

This verse connects to the broader Quranic narrative of Ibrahim’s life, where his unwavering trust in Allah is tested repeatedly, from confronting idolatry to accepting the command to sacrifice his son. Here, his momentary surprise highlights the emotional realism of prophets—they experienced human feelings yet channeled them into deeper submission. The angels’ eventual clarification (leading to the birth of Ishaq) reaffirms that Allah’s plans transcend worldly constraints.  

For modern Muslims, this verse teaches resilience in trusting Allah’s timing. In an era where instant gratification is prioritized, Ibrahim’s story reminds us that blessings—whether children, opportunities, or answered prayers—can arrive unexpectedly, even when circumstances seem insurmountable. The key Arabic terms *bashara* and *kibar* also invite reflection: How do we respond to divine promises amid life’s “old ages”—times of stagnation, doubt, or exhaustion? Like Ibrahim, we are called to embrace hope, recognize Allah’s limitless power, and remain open to miracles in everyday struggles. The verse ultimately celebrates faith that coexists with human vulnerability, guiding believers to anchor their hearts in divine wisdom rather than fleeting worldly logic.
54.layer2:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:54), Prophet Ibrahim’s response to the angels’ glad tidings of a son—*"Have you given me good tidings although old age has come upon me?"*—is interpreted by classical Shia scholars as an expression of awe at divine power rather than doubt. This verse, situated within the narrative of Ibrahim’s lifelong trials, underscores theological principles central to Shia thought, particularly the interplay between human limitation and divine omnipotence. 

Al-Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, clarifies that Ibrahim’s rhetorical question reflects his astonishment at the miraculous reversal of natural limitations—his advanced age and his wife’s barrenness (Quran 51:29)—not skepticism. Shia theology emphasizes the infallibility (*ismah*) of prophets, affirming that their words and actions are divinely guided. Here, Ibrahim’s response serves a pedagogical purpose: to highlight the extraordinary nature of God’s decree, thereby reinforcing the principle that divine will transcends apparent worldly impossibilities. Al-Tabrisi notes that the phrase *"Then of what do you inform?"* invites elaboration, allowing the angels to expand on the wisdom behind the miracle, thereby deepening human understanding of divine grace.

Al-Tabtabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands on this by framing Ibrahim’s reaction as a reflection of the human condition’s inherent constraints. The prophet’s acknowledgment of his physical frailty contrasts with his unwavering recognition of God’s limitless power, illustrating the Shia theological axiom that true reliance (*tawakkul*) involves submitting to divine wisdom even when it defies empirical logic. This aligns with the broader Quranic theme of God’s ability to "create what He wills" (3:47), a principle recurrently affirmed in narratives of miraculous births, such as those of Yahya and Isa. 

Shia commentators also connect this verse to the doctrine of divine testing (*ibtila*). Ibrahim’s life exemplifies perseverance through trials, and his questioning here becomes a model for believers to seek clarity while maintaining absolute trust in God’s plan. The Imams of the Ahl al-Bayt, as narrated in traditions, often emphasized that divine promises are fulfilled in ways that transcend human expectation, urging followers to cultivate patience and spiritual insight. 

In jurisprudence, this narrative reinforces the ethical obligation to embrace hope (*raja*) amid adversity, a principle embedded in Shia spirituality. The verse thus becomes a nexus of theology, ethics, and spirituality, illustrating how divine power operates beyond temporal limitations while affirming the prophetic mission’s integrity. Through classical exegesis, Shia scholarship harmonizes Ibrahim’s human astonishment with his prophetic certainty, offering a nuanced understanding of faith in divine providence.
54.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:54), Prophet Ibrahim’s astonishment at the angels’ announcement of a son despite his advanced age resonates deeply in our era of scientific skepticism and existential uncertainty. Contemporary Shia scholars, like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, emphasize that Ibrahim’s question—“Do you give me glad tidings when old age has reached me?”—isn’t disbelief but a human quest to reconcile divine promise with tangible reality. This mirrors modern struggles to align faith with rational inquiry, a theme explored by scholars such as Dr. Liyakat Takim, who highlights how Shia theology encourages “faith through critical engagement,” not blind acceptance.  

Scientifically, the verse invites reflection on aging and possibility. While Ibrahim and Sarah’s parenthood in old age defied biological norms, modern fertility science—through IVF or egg freezing—echoes this narrative of transcending natural limits. Yet the Quranic story transcends biology, challenging societal ageism that dismisses the elderly’s potential. In a youth-centric world, this verse reaffirms that purpose and blessings aren’t bound by age—a lesson for societies grappling with aging populations and intergenerational divides.  

Globally, the verse speaks to despair in crises like climate change or pandemics, where hope seems irrational. Ibrahim’s story models resilience: trusting in divine wisdom even when circumstances appear bleak. Philosophically, it aligns with existentialist thought—finding meaning amid absurdity, as scholar Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali notes, bridging Islamic theology and universal human struggles.  

Interfaith parallels abound: Christians and Jews revere Abraham’s late fatherhood, while Hindu texts celebrate elder sages receiving divine boons. These shared narratives offer common ground for interreligious dialogue on aging, hope, and purpose. Ultimately, Surah Al-Hijr 54 urges a modern balance—embracing wonder without abandoning reason, and recognizing that the impossible often unfolds through channels we’ve yet to comprehend.
54.layer4:
In Surah Al-Hijr verse 54, Prophet Ibrahim (AS) expresses wonder at the angels' glad tidings of a son despite his advanced age. Through the lens of Ahlul Bayt's teachings, this verse becomes a profound lesson on transcending apparent limitations through divine connection and submission to Allah's will. Imam Ali (AS) teaches in Nahj al-Balagha: "How can the One Who created him in the beginning be unable to repeat his creation?" This encapsulates the principle that Allah's power operates beyond material constraints, urging believers to see with the "eye of certainty" (ayn al-yaqeen) rather than mere physical perception.

Lady Fatimah (AS) exemplified this truth through her famous declaration: "Allah has made faith your purification from shirk." Her words remind us that true spiritual vision emerges when we recognize divine power beyond worldly causes. The Imams taught that every apparent impossibility becomes possible through wilayah - the channel of divine grace flowing through the purified successors of the Prophet (PBUH). 

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (AS) comments on this verse: "When the Friend of Allah (Ibrahim) doubted, it was not doubt in his Lord, but astonishment at the perfection of His wisdom." This reveals the distinction between intellectual questioning and spiritual certainty. The Imams encourage believers to embrace such moments of wonder as opportunities to deepen tawakkul (reliance on Allah), transforming shock into spiritual elevation.

Practical guidance from this verse lies in cultivating patient trust (sabr) during life's paradoxes. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) prays in Sahifa Sajjadiyya: "My Lord, make me content with Your decree until I do not prefer what You delay over what You advance." When facing seeming impossibilities, we are taught to: 1) Remember Allah's limitless power through daily dhikr 2) Study the lives of the Imams who manifested miracles through divine connection 3) Renew our allegiance to the Living Imam (Mahdi AJ), the perfect manifestation of Allah's timeless power.

True spiritual birth, the Imams teach, occurs not through physical means but through the light of guidance. As Prophet Ibrahim (AS) received Isaac as a gift beyond nature, we receive the greater gift of Imamah - the eternal lifeline connecting creation to the Creator. Our astonishment at divine gifts should fuel greater submission, not doubt, remembering Imam Ali's (AS) counsel: "The system of religion is established through what the eyes see not, the hands touch not, and the imagination encompasses not.

لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے مشہور اعلامیے کے ذریعہ اس سچائی کی مثال دی: "اللہ نے شرک سے آپ کے طہارت کو اعتماد کیا ہے۔" اس کے الفاظ ہمیں یاد دلاتے ہیں کہ جب ہم دنیاوی وجوہات سے بالاتر الہی طاقت کو پہچانتے ہیں تو حقیقی روحانی وژن ابھرتا ہے۔ اماموں نے یہ سکھایا کہ ہر واضح ناممکن ولیہ کے ذریعہ ممکن ہوتا ہے - نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم کے پاک جانشینوں کے ذریعہ الہی فضل کا چینل۔ 

امام جعفر السادق (ع) اس آیت پر تبصرے کرتے ہیں: "جب اللہ کے دوست (ابراہیم) کے دوست نے شک کیا تو ، اس کے رب میں یہ شک نہیں تھا ، بلکہ اس کی دانشمندی کے کمال پر حیرت تھی۔" اس سے دانشورانہ پوچھ گچھ اور روحانی یقین کے مابین فرق ظاہر ہوتا ہے۔ اماموں نے مومنوں کو حیرت کے ایسے لمحات کو گلے لگانے کی ترغیب دی ہے کیونکہ تاواکول (اللہ پر انحصار) کو گہرا کرنے کے مواقع کے طور پر ، صدمے کو روحانی بلندی میں تبدیل کیا جاتا ہے۔

اس آیت سے عملی رہنمائی زندگی کے تضادات کے دوران مریضوں کے اعتماد (SABR) کی کاشت میں ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام زین العبدین (ع) ساہفا سججدیہ میں دعا کرتے ہیں: "میرے رب ، مجھے اپنے فرمان سے مطمئن بنائیں جب تک کہ میں آپ کو اس بات کو ترجیح نہیں دیتا کہ آپ جس چیز کی پیش قدمی کرتے ہیں اس پر آپ کو تاخیر نہیں ہوتی۔" جب بظاہر ناممکنات کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے تو ، ہمیں یہ سکھایا جاتا ہے کہ: 1) روزنامہ کے ذریعہ اللہ کی لامحدود طاقت کو یاد رکھیں۔

حقیقی روحانی پیدائش ، امام پڑھاتے ہیں ، جسمانی ذرائع سے نہیں بلکہ رہنمائی کی روشنی میں ہوتا ہے۔ جیسا کہ نبی. ابراہیم (ع) کو فطرت سے بالاتر ایک تحفہ کے طور پر اسحاق موصول ہوا ، ہمیں امامہ کا زیادہ سے زیادہ تحفہ ملتا ہے۔ خدائی تحائف میں ہماری حیرت سے زیادہ تر پیش کش کو ہوا دینا چاہئے ، اس میں شک نہیں ، امام علی (ع) کے مشورے کو یاد کرتے ہوئے: "مذہب کا نظام قائم کیا جاتا ہے جس کے ذریعے آنکھیں نہیں دیکھتے ، ہاتھ نہیں چھوتے ہیں ، اور تخیل پر محیط نہیں ہے۔
54.layer5:
The verse depicts Prophet Ibrahim’s response to divine tidings of a son in his old age, prompting scholarly discussions across traditions about prophetic psychology, divine grace, and human humility. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur that Ibrahim’s rhetorical question (“Have you given me good tidings although old age has come upon me?”) reflects awe at Allah’s power to transcend natural limitations, not doubt in His promise. Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia) emphasize that Ibrahim’s astonishment underscores his profound recognition of divine omnipotence (*Al-Mizan*; *Jami al-Bayan*). Similarly, Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) highlight the thematic link to earlier prophets like Zakariyya, framing such narratives as reaffirming Allah’s ability to grant blessings against worldly odds.  

Divergences emerge in nuanced theological emphases. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi and Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) contextualize Ibrahim’s reaction as a natural human expression of wonder, aligning with the Sunni view of prophets as exemplary yet emotionally relatable figures. In contrast, Shia exegetes such as Qummi (*Tafsir al-Qummi*) and Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) stress the *‘ismah* (infallibility) of prophets, interpreting Ibrahim’s words as a rhetorical device to magnify the miracle’s significance rather than an expression of personal uncertainty. This reflects the Shia theological principle that prophets, while fully human, transcend ordinary emotional fallibility through divine protection.  

Historically, these differences stem from distinct hermeneutical priorities. Sunni tafsir often prioritizes literal and contextual analysis rooted in *hadith* transmission, whereas Shia scholarship integrates the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, as seen in Qummi’s reliance on Imam al-Baqir’s interpretations. Such variations, however, do not significantly impact religious practice but enrich theological discourse on prophetic character. Both traditions ultimately celebrate the verse as a testament to Allah’s boundless power and the honor of Ibrahim’s steadfastness, demonstrating how shared scriptural foundations yield complementary insights across Islamic thought.

55.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:55), Allah recounts the moment when angels visited Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) to deliver the joyful news of a son, Isaac (Ishaq), in his old age. The verse reads: *"They said, ‘We have given you good tidings in truth, so do not be of the despairing’"*. Here, the angels address Ibrahim’s potential hesitation after years of longing for a child, reassuring him that their message is rooted in divine certainty (*bil-haqq*), not mere hope. The term *bashsharnaka* ("we have given you good tidings") reflects the Quranic theme of divine promises fulfilled through Allah’s wisdom, while *al-qaniteen* ("the despairing") warns against losing hope in Allah’s mercy—a spiritual state Islam strongly discourages, as despair implies distrust in His power and timing.

Historically, this verse emerges within Ibrahim’s lifelong test of faith. Despite enduring exile, fire, and delayed parenthood, he remained steadfast. The angels’ reassurance highlights that even prophets, though divinely guided, experience human emotions, requiring reminders to renew trust (*tawakkul*). The "truth" (*haqq*) of their message also underscores that Allah’s plans transcend worldly logic—Ibrahim’s wife, Sarah, was far beyond childbearing age, yet Allah’s will defies limitations.

For modern Muslims, this verse encourages resilience amid life’s trials. Whether facing personal struggles, societal challenges, or global crises, despair is not an option. The verse teaches that divine promises—such as justice, relief, and eternal reward—are certain, even if their fulfillment seems distant. Practically, this means cultivating patience (*sabr*), reflecting on past blessings as proof of Allah’s care, and seeking strength through prayer and trust. In Shia tradition, this aligns with the concept of *intizar* (awaiting divine justice), urging believers to remain hopeful while actively working toward righteousness. By internalizing the angels’ words to Ibrahim, Muslims today can transform uncertainty into faith, knowing Allah’s truth always prevails.
55.layer2:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:55), the divine reassurance extended to Prophet Ibrahim (AS) through angelic messengers encapsulates profound theological themes central to Shia exegesis. The verse’s admonition, "do not be of the despairing," addresses both the human dimension of prophetic experience and the ontological necessity of unwavering trust (*tawakkul*) in divine wisdom. Classical commentators such as Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* situate this exchange within the broader narrative of Ibrahim’s longing for progeny amid advanced age, interpreting the angels’ declaration as affirming the certainty (*haqq*) of divine promises. Tabrisi notes that while momentary astonishment at extraordinary news is intrinsic to human nature, prophets—protected by *ismah* (infallibility)—transcend doubt through their perfected connection to divine will. This aligns with the Shia emphasis on prophetic and Imamic infallibility as pillars of spiritual guidance.

In *Al-Mizan*, Allamah Tabatabai elaborates on the theological tension between human emotional responses and transcendent certainty, arguing that Ibrahim’s potential "despair" (*qanitin*) reflects not disbelief but a natural human reflex to temporal limitations. The angels’ counsel thus becomes a didactic moment, illustrating the necessity of rising above transient perceptions to embrace the eternal reality (*haqiqah*) of Allah’s plan. Shia theology interprets such episodes as affirming the compatibility of human vulnerability with prophetic perfection, as the Ahlul Bayt later exemplified in balancing profound trials with unshakeable faith.

The verse also intersects with Shia ethical jurisprudence, which categorizes despair (*qunut*) as a spiritual ailment contradicting the principle of *raja* (hope in divine mercy). Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in *Bihar al-Anwar*, teaches that despair "locks the doors of Allah’s mercy," positioning the angels’ reassurance as a universal injunction for believers to cultivate *yaqin* (certainty). This interplay between divine promise and human response underscores the Shia worldview of existence as a continuum of tests demanding active surrender to the *mashiyyah* (divine will), a theme recurrent in the supplications of the Imams. Thus, the verse transcends its historical context, offering a timeless paradigm for navigating earthly trials through unwavering reliance on divine truth.
55.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:55), the angels reassure Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) with the words, *“We have given you good tidings in truth, so do not be of the despairing.”* Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, emphasize that this verse balances divine reassurance with human responsibility. The “truth” here is not merely a promise of progeny but a broader principle: certainty in God’s plan, even when circumstances seem impossible. Today, this resonates in a world grappling with existential crises—climate change, political instability, and social fragmentation—where despair often feels like a default response.  

Modern psychology echoes this wisdom: studies on resilience and hope theory, like those by psychologist C.R. Snyder, affirm that hope—rooted in agency and pathways thinking—is vital for mental and communal well-being. The verse’s call to reject despair aligns with this, urging believers to anchor themselves in actionable faith rather than passive resignation. For instance, climate activists, inspired by both scientific urgency and spiritual conviction, embody this principle by transforming anxiety into advocacy.  

Socially, the verse speaks to marginalized communities facing systemic injustice. Scholars like Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi highlight that divine “good tidings” are not passive guarantees but invitations to co-create justice. In Shia theology, this mirrors the ethos of Imam Ali’s teachings on perseverance amid adversity.  

Interfaith parallels abound: Jewish and Christian traditions similarly valorize hope (Tikvah in Judaism, Elpis in Christianity) as an act of resistance. In multicultural contexts, the verse becomes a bridge, emphasizing shared spiritual resilience against dehumanization.  

Ultimately, 15:55 is a timeless antidote to nihilism. It challenges us to pair faith with effort, trusting divine wisdom while actively nurturing hope—a lesson as critical for pandemic recovery as for addressing inequities in our interconnected world. As the Qur’an reminds, despair is not an option when truth and transcendence guide the way.
55.layer4:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:55), the angels address Prophet Ibrahim (as) with divine reassurance: *"We have given you good tidings in truth, so do not be of the despairing."* This verse radiates the eternal principle of unwavering trust in Allah’s promises, a theme deeply illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as). The command to shun despair is not merely a call to optimism but a profound spiritual mandate rooted in the reality of divine providence and the luminous guidance of the Imams (as).

Imam Ali (as) teaches in *Nahj al-Balagha*: *"Despair is the greatest sin, for it makes you see the Divine Mercy as limited and your own suffering as greater than His Compassion."* This mirrors the angels’ exhortation to Ibrahim (as) — to reject despair is to affirm the boundless reality of Allah’s plan. The Ahlul Bayt (as) embody this truth, for their lives were marked by trials transcended through unshakable *tawakkul* (reliance on Allah). Lady Fatimah (as), despite enduring immense hardship after her father’s passing, declared: *"Allah is my Sufficiency, and the Best of Trustees"* — a testament to surrendering despair to divine wisdom.

The sixth Imam, Ja’far al-Sadiq (as), expands on this balance between hope and reverence: *"A believer’s heart is suspended between *khawf* (fear) and *raja* (hope). Both must be equal, for neither is sound without the other."* True hope, as taught by the Imams (as), is not passive wishing but an active alignment with Allah’s will through the recognition of *Wilayah* — the spiritual guardianship of the Ahlul Bayt (as). Their teachings act as the *"rope of Allah"* (Qur’an 3:103), pulling souls from the abyss of hopelessness into the light of certainty.

Practically, the verse invites believers to anchor themselves in daily remembrance (*dhikr*) and supplication (*dua*), seeking the intercession (*tawassul*) of the Ahlul Bayt (as). Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) guides in *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya*: *"When grief strikes, turn to Allah through us, the People of the House, for we are the gate to His Mercy."* Regular recitation of *Salawat*, reflection on the trials and triumphs of the Imams (as), and conscious rejection of negative thoughts nurture a heart fortified against despair.

Ultimately, this verse and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as) remind us that divine promises are inseparable from divine tests. As Imam al-Baqir (as) states: *"Trials are the polish of the heart, preparing it to reflect the light of certainty."* To abandon despair is to affirm the truth of *Imamah* — that Allah’s guidance, manifested through the Infallibles (as), eternally illuminates the path to His Infinite Mercy.

سورہ الہجر (15:55) میں ، اللہ اس لمحے کا ذکر کرتا ہے جب فرشتوں نے اپنے بڑھاپے میں بیٹے ، اسحاق (اسحاق) کی خوش کن خبر پیش کرنے کے لئے حضرت ابراہیم (ابراہیم) کا دورہ کیا۔ آیت میں لکھا گیا ہے: *"انہوں نے کہا ،‘ ہم نے آپ کو سچائی میں اچھی خبریں دی ہیں ، لہذا مایوسی کا شکار نہ ہوں ’ *۔ یہاں ، فرشتوں نے ایک بچے کی آرزو کے کئی سالوں کے بعد ابراہیم کی ممکنہ ہچکچاہٹ کو مخاطب کیا ، اور اسے یقین دلایا کہ ان کا پیغام الہی یقین (*بل-ہق*) میں ہے ، محض امید نہیں۔ اصطلاح * بششارناکا * ("ہم نے آپ کو اچھی خبریں دی ہیں") اللہ کی دانشمندی کے ذریعہ پورا ہونے والے خدائی وعدوں کے قرآنی موضوع کی عکاسی کرتی ہے ، جبکہ * الکانیٹین * ("مایوسی") اللہ کی رحمت میں امید کھونے کے خلاف انتباہ کرتا ہے۔

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ آیت ابراہیم کے ایمان کے زندگی بھر کے امتحان میں ابھری ہے۔ جلاوطنی ، آگ اور والدینیت میں تاخیر کے باوجود ، وہ ثابت قدم رہا۔ فرشتوں کی یقین دہانی پر روشنی ڈالی گئی ہے کہ یہاں تک کہ نبیوں کو بھی ، اگرچہ خدائی رہنمائی کی گئی ہے ، لیکن انسانی جذبات کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے ، جس میں اعتماد کی تجدید کے لئے یاد دہانیوں کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے (*تاواکول*)۔ ان کے پیغام کی "سچائی" (*حق*) بھی اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے کہ اللہ کے منصوبے دنیاوی منطق سے بالاتر ہیں۔

جدید مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت زندگی کی آزمائشوں کے دوران لچک کی حوصلہ افزائی کرتی ہے۔ چاہے ذاتی جدوجہد ، معاشرتی چیلنجوں ، یا عالمی بحرانوں کا سامنا کرنا پڑے ، مایوسی کوئی آپشن نہیں ہے۔ آیت یہ سکھاتی ہے کہ خدائی وعدے - جیسے انصاف ، ریلیف ، اور ابدی اجر - یقینی طور پر ، چاہے ان کی تکمیل دور ہی دکھائی دے۔ عملی طور پر ، اس کا مطلب ہے صبر کاشت کرنا (*سبر*) ، اللہ کی دیکھ بھال کے ثبوت کے طور پر ماضی کی نعمتوں پر غور کرنا ، اور نماز اور اعتماد کے ذریعہ طاقت کے حصول کے لئے۔ شیعہ روایت میں ، یہ * انٹیزر * (الہی انصاف کے منتظر) کے تصور کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے ، اور مومنین پر زور دیتا ہے کہ وہ راستبازی کی طرف فعال طور پر کام کرتے ہوئے امید مند رہیں۔ فرشتوں کے الفاظ ابراہیم کو داخل کرکے ، مسلمان آج بھی غیر یقینی صورتحال کو ایمان میں بدل سکتے ہیں ، اور یہ جانتے ہوئے کہ اللہ کی سچائی ہمیشہ غالب رہتی ہے۔
55.layer2_urdu:
سورہ الہجر (15:55) میں ، الہی یقین دہانی نے فرشتہ کے میسینجرز کے ذریعہ حضرت ابراہیم (ع) کو بڑھایا۔ آیت کی نصیحت ، "مایوس کن نہ ہو" ، پیشن گوئی کے تجربے کی انسانی جہت اور الہی حکمت میں غیر متزلزل اعتماد (*توقکول*) کی اونٹولوجیکل ضرورت دونوں کو حل کرتی ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین جیسے*مجمہ البیان*میں تبریسی اس تبادلے کو ابراہیم کی اعلی درجے کی عمر کے دوران اولاد کی خواہش کی وسیع داستان کے تحت پیش کرتے ہیں ، اور فرشتوں کے اعلان کو الہی وعدوں کی یقین (*حق*) کی تصدیق کرتے ہیں۔ تبریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ غیر معمولی خبروں میں لمحہ بہ لمحہ حیرت کا باعث انسانی فطرت کے اندرونی ہے ، انبیاء - جو * عثمہ * (عدم استحکام) کے ذریعہ تیار کردہ ہیں۔ یہ روحانی رہنمائی کے ستون کے طور پر پیشن گوئی اور امامک عدم استحکام پر شیعہ پر زور دینے کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے۔

*المزان*میں ، الامہ تبتابائی نے انسانی جذباتی ردعمل اور ماورائی یقین کے مابین مذہبی تناؤ کی وضاحت کی ہے ، اور یہ استدلال کیا ہے کہ ابراہیم کی ممکنہ "مایوسی" (*کنیٹین*) کفر نہیں بلکہ عارضی حدود کے لئے قدرتی انسانی اضطراب کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔ اس طرح فرشتوں کا مشورہ ایک مشغول لمحہ بن جاتا ہے ، جو اللہ کے منصوبے کی ابدی حقیقت (*حققہ*) کو گلے لگانے کے لئے عارضی تاثرات سے بالاتر ہونے کی ضرورت کو ظاہر کرتا ہے۔ شیعہ الہیات اس طرح کے اقساط کی ترجمانی کرتی ہے جیسے پیشن گوئی کے کمال کے ساتھ انسانی کمزوری کی مطابقت کی تصدیق کرتی ہے ، کیونکہ بعد میں اہل بیت نے غیر متزلزل عقیدے کے ساتھ گہری آزمائشوں کو متوازن کرنے کی مثال دی ہے۔

یہ آیت شیعہ اخلاقی فقہ کے ساتھ بھی آپس میں ملتی ہے ، جو مایوسی (*کونٹ*) کو روحانی بیماری کے طور پر درجہ بندی کرتی ہے جو*راجا*(الہی رحمت میں امید) کے اصول سے متصادم ہے۔ امام جعفر السادق ، جیسا کہ *بہار الانور *میں پیش کیا گیا ہے ، وہ سکھاتا ہے کہ مایوسی "اللہ کے رحم کے دروازوں کو لاک کرتی ہے ،" فرشتوں کو "یاقین *(یقین دہانی) کاشت کرنے کے لئے مومنوں کو عالمی حکم نامے کی حیثیت سے ایک عالمی حکم نامہ قرار دیتا ہے۔ خدائی وعدے اور انسانی ردعمل کے مابین یہ باہمی تعل .ق شیعہ ورلڈ ویو کو وجود کے نظریہ کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے جس میں * مشیح * (الہی مرضی) کے فعال ہتھیار ڈالنے کا مطالبہ کرنے والے ٹیسٹوں کے تسلسل کے طور پر ، جو اماموں کی فراہمی میں ایک تھیم بار بار ہوتا ہے۔ اس طرح ، آیت اپنے تاریخی سیاق و سباق سے بالاتر ہے ، جو الہی سچائی پر غیر متزلزل انحصار کے ذریعہ زمینی آزمائشوں کو نیویگیٹ کرنے کے لئے ایک لازوال نمونہ پیش کرتی ہے۔
55.layer3_urdu:
سورہ الہجر (15:55) میں ، فرشتوں نے ان الفاظ کے ساتھ نبی اکرم صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم کو یقین دلاتے ہوئے کہا ، "ہم نے آپ کو سچائی کے ساتھ اچھ tid ی خبریں دی ہیں ، لہذا مایوسی کا شکار نہ ہوں۔" یہاں "سچائی" محض اولاد کا وعدہ نہیں بلکہ ایک وسیع تر اصول ہے: خدا کے منصوبے میں یقین ، یہاں تک کہ جب حالات ناممکن معلوم ہوتے ہیں۔ آج ، یہ ایسی دنیا میں گونجتی ہے جو وجودی بحرانوں - اجتماعی تبدیلی ، سیاسی عدم استحکام اور معاشرتی ٹکڑے ٹکڑے کر رہی ہے۔ جہاں مایوسی اکثر پہلے سے طے شدہ ردعمل کی طرح محسوس ہوتی ہے۔  

جدید نفسیات اس دانشمندی کی بازگشت کرتی ہے: ماہر نفسیات سی آر سنائیڈر کی طرح لچک اور امید کے نظریہ پر مطالعہ ، اس بات کی تصدیق کرتے ہیں کہ ایجنسی اور راستوں کی سوچ میں امید-ذہنی اور فرقہ وارانہ بہبود کے لئے بہت ضروری ہے۔ آیت کی مایوسی کو مسترد کرنے کا مطالبہ اس کے ساتھ منسلک ہے ، اور مومنوں پر زور دیتا ہے کہ وہ غیر فعال استعفیٰ کے بجائے خود کو قابل عمل عقیدے میں لنگر انداز کریں۔ مثال کے طور پر ، سائنسی عجلت اور روحانی یقین دونوں سے متاثر آب و ہوا کے کارکنان ، اضطراب کو وکالت میں تبدیل کرکے اس اصول کو مجسم بناتے ہیں۔  

معاشرتی طور پر ، آیت پسماندہ طبقات کو سیسٹیمیٹک ناانصافی کا سامنا کرنے والی بات کی بات کرتی ہے۔ ڈاکٹر رضا شاہ-کاظمی جیسے اسکالرز نے اجاگر کیا ہے کہ خدائی "اچھی خبریں" غیر فعال ضمانتیں نہیں ہیں بلکہ انصاف کو تخلیق کرنے کے لئے دعوت نامے ہیں۔ شیعہ الہیات میں ، یہ مشکلات کے درمیان استقامت سے متعلق امام علی کی تعلیمات کی اخلاقیات کی آئینہ دار ہے۔  

انٹرفیتھ متوازی بہت سارے ہیں: یہودی اور عیسائی روایات بھی اسی طرح امید کی قدر کرتے ہیں (یہودیت میں ٹکوا ، عیسائیت میں ایلپس) مزاحمت کے ایک عمل کے طور پر۔ کثیر الثقافتی سیاق و سباق میں ، آیت ایک پل بن جاتی ہے ، جس میں غیر انسانیت کے خلاف مشترکہ روحانی لچک پر زور دیا جاتا ہے۔  

آخر کار ، 15:55 نحلیزم کا لازوال تریاق ہے۔ یہ ہمیں چیلنج کرتا ہے کہ ہم کوشش کے ساتھ ایمان کو جوڑیں ، الہی حکمت پر بھروسہ کریں جبکہ امید کی فعال طور پر پرورش کریں - ایک سبق جیسا کہ ہماری باہم وابستہ دنیا میں عدم مساوات کو دور کرنے کے لئے وبائی بیماری کی بحالی کے لئے ایک اہم سبق ہے۔ جیسا کہ قرآن مجید یاد دلاتا ہے ، مایوسی کوئی آپشن نہیں ہے جب سچائی اور عبور کی راہنمائی ہوتی ہے۔
55.layer4_urdu:
سورہ الہجر (15:55) میں ، فرشتوں نے نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم کو ابراہیم (ع) کو خدائی یقین دہانی سے مخاطب کیا: * "ہم نے آپ کو حقیقت میں اچھ .ی خبریں دی ہیں ، لہذا مایوسی کا شکار نہ ہوں۔" مایوسی سے دور ہونے کا حکم محض امید پرستی کا مطالبہ نہیں ہے بلکہ ایک گہرا روحانی مینڈیٹ ہے جو الہی پروویڈنس کی حقیقت اور اماموں (AS) کی برائٹ رہنمائی کی حقیقت میں ہے۔

امام علی (ع) *ناہج البالاگھا میں پڑھاتے ہیں *: *"مایوسی سب سے بڑا گناہ ہے ، کیونکہ اس سے آپ کو الہی رحمت کو محدود اور آپ کی اپنی تکلیف کو اس کی شفقت سے کہیں زیادہ دیکھا جاتا ہے۔" اہل بیت (ع) اس سچائی کو مجسم بناتے ہیں ، کیونکہ ان کی زندگیوں کو غیر متزلزل * توواکول * (اللہ پر انحصار) کے ذریعے عبور کیا گیا تھا۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے والد کے انتقال کے بعد بے حد مشکلات برداشت کرنے کے باوجود ، اعلان کیا: * "اللہ میری کافییت ہے ، اور بہترین ٹرسٹی" * - الہی حکمت کے سامنے مایوسی کو ہتھیار ڈالنے کا ثبوت ہے۔

چھٹا امام ، جافر السادق (ع) ، امید اور عقیدت کے مابین اس توازن پر پھیلتا ہے: * "ایک مومن کا دل * Khawf * (خوف) اور * راجہ * (امید) کے مابین معطل ہوجاتا ہے۔ دونوں کے برابر ہونا چاہئے ، نہ کہ دوسرے کے ساتھ ،" صحیح امید ہے ، لیکن یہ غیر یقینی ہے ، جیسے کہ امام (جیسے) کی تعلیم حاصل نہیں کی جاتی ہے ، لیکن یہ غیر فعال نہیں ہے ، جیسا کہ امام (بطور) سکھایا جاتا ہے ، یہ ایک غیر فعال نہیں ہے ، لیکن یہ غیر فعال نہیں ہے۔ * ولیہ * - اہل بیت (ع) کی روحانی سرپرستی۔ ان کی تعلیمات * "رسی آف اللہ" * (قرآن مجید 3: 103) کے طور پر کام کرتی ہیں ، اور جانوں کو ناامیدی کی طرف سے یقین کی روشنی میں کھینچتی ہیں۔

عملی طور پر ، آیت مومنوں کو دعوت دیتی ہے کہ وہ خود کو روزانہ کی یاد (*dhikr*) اور التجا (*DUA*) میں لنگر انداز کریں ، جو اہل بائٹ (AS) کی شفاعت (*tawassul*) کی تلاش میں ہیں۔ امام زین الیبدین (ع) *ساہفا الصجدیہ میں رہنمائی کرتے ہیں *: *"جب غم سے حملہ ہوتا ہے تو ، گھر کے لوگ ہمارے وسیلے سے اللہ کی طرف رجوع کرتے ہیں ، کیونکہ ہم اس کی رحمت کا دروازہ ہیں۔

آخر کار ، یہ آیت اور اہل بیت (ع) کی تعلیمات ہمیں یاد دلاتی ہیں کہ خدائی وعدے خدائی ٹیسٹوں سے لازم و ملزوم ہیں۔ جیسا کہ امام البقیر (ع) میں کہا گیا ہے: * "آزمائشیں دل کی پالش ہیں ، اور اسے یقین کی روشنی کی عکاسی کرنے کی تیاری کر رہی ہیں۔"
55.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hijr 15:55, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s core narrative context: angels reassuring Prophet Ibrahim (AS) of divine truthfulness in granting him a son despite advanced age, urging him to avoid despair (qanṭ). Classical sources like Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize linguistic unity, noting *qanṭ* denotes despair rooted in distrust of divine promises—a stance universally condemned. Al-Qurtubi and Al-Tusi’s *Al-Tibyan* similarly stress the ethical imperative of *tawakkul* (trust in God), reflecting shared theological ground on hope as a pillar of faith.

Divergences emerge in theological framing. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir contextualize Ibrahim’s momentary doubt as a human response, mitigated by his swift return to patience (*sabr*), aligning with Sunni emphasis on prophetic infallibility (*ismah*) as conditional rather than absolute. In contrast, Shia works like Al-Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* interpret Ibrahim’s state as astonishment (*ta‘ajjub*), not genuine despair, preserving the Prophet’s perfected spiritual station—a view rooted in the Shia doctrine of *ismah al-anbiya* (absolute infallibility of prophets). Al-Qummi’s *Tafsir* further links the angels’ reassurance to divine support for the *Ahl al-Bayt* during trials, reflecting Shia hermeneutics that intertwine Quranic narratives with Imamah theology.

Practically, Sunni interpretations reinforce resilience through communal remembrance of prophetic trials, while Shia readings often inspire emulation of the *Ahl al-Bayt*’s unwavering faith amid adversity. Historically, these differences stem from distinct epistemological frameworks: Sunni exegesis prioritizes *athar* (narrations from companions) and linguistic analysis, whereas Shia tradition integrates the Imams’ hermeneutical authority. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s timeless lesson against despair, demonstrating how shared scripture nurtures complementary spiritual insights.

56.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:56), Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) responds to divine messengers who brought him both the joyous news of a son and the warning of impending punishment for the people of Lut. His profound statement, *"And who despairs of the mercy of his Lord except for those astray?"* captures a timeless truth about unwavering faith. The verse challenges the mindset of hopelessness, framing it as a spiritual deviation. The Arabic term *yaqnaṭu* (يَقْنَطُ) signifies a deep, paralyzing despair that severs one’s connection to divine compassion, while *al-dalloon* (الضَّالُّونَ) refers to those who have lost their way—those who, by rejecting faith or doubting Allah’s power, cut themselves off from hope. Historically, this verse emerged in a context where Ibrahim, despite his advanced age, accepted the miraculous news of a child with trust, embodying the opposite of despair. His rhetorical question underscores that hopelessness is not just an emotional state but a symptom of misguidance.  

For modern Muslims, this verse serves as a remedy for moments of doubt or hardship. In times of personal struggle, societal crises, or global uncertainty, it reminds believers that despair is incompatible with faith. The Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Ali, emphasized that reliance on Allah’s mercy (*rahmah*) is the cornerstone of resilience. Practically, this means turning to prayer, reflecting on past blessings, and trusting that divine wisdom transcends immediate understanding. It also calls for community support: uplifting others who feel overwhelmed, embodying hope through action, and rejecting narratives of defeat. By internalizing this verse, Muslims reinforce that true guidance lies in anchoring the heart to Allah’s limitless mercy, even when the path seems unclear.
56.layer2:
In Surah al-Hijr (15:56), the Quran recounts Prophet Ibrahim’s rhetorical response to those questioning Allah’s promise of granting him a son in old age: *“Who despairs of the mercy of his Lord except those astray?”* Classical Shia exegetes, drawing upon the theological framework of the Ahlul Bayt, elucidate this verse as a profound discourse on divine mercy, human agency, and the spiritual perils of despair (ya’s). 

Imam Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, underscores that despair in divine mercy constitutes a fundamental deviation (dalal) from tawhid, as it implicitly denies Allah’s omnibenevolence and omnipotence. He observes that true faith necessitates unwavering hope in Allah’s grace, even amidst apparent impossibilities, for “His mercy encompasses all things” (Quran 7:156). Despair, in this context, is not mere emotional despondency but a cognitive rejection of Allah’s attributes, rendering one akin to the “astray” (al-dallun) who sever their ontological reliance on the Creator. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, aligns with this view, noting that Ibrahim’s rhetorical question rebukes the mechanistic worldview of those who limit divine power to material causality, thereby failing to perceive the metaphysical reality of Allah’s boundless rahma.

Shia theology uniquely links this verse to the doctrine of divine justice (‘adl) and the necessity of prophetic and Imamic guidance. The “astray” are those who, by rejecting the divinely appointed guides (the Ahlul Bayt), become susceptible to misinterpreting Allah’s mercy as either unconditional leniency (leading to moral complacency) or unattainable remoteness (breeding despair). The sixth Imam, Jafar al-Sadiq, is reported to have stated that “hope and fear are the two wings of faith”; despair disrupts this equilibrium, corroding the believer’s connection to the Ma’sumin, whose intercession (shafa’a) epitomizes divine mercy in action.

Jurisprudentially, despair holds implications for acts of worship and repentance. Classical scholars argue that abandoning prayer or repentance due to hopelessness invalidates the believer’s submission, as it contradicts the Quranic assurance that “Allah forgives all sins” (39:53). Thus, the verse implicitly reaffirms the Shia emphasis on perpetual spiritual striving (jihad al-nafs) under the guidance of the Imams, who embody the living channels of Allah’s mercy. In essence, the verse encapsulates a core axiom of Shia thought: to despair is to deny the very ontology of hope inscribed in creation by the All-Merciful.
56.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:56), Prophet Ibrahim’s rhetorical question—*“Who despairs of their Lord’s mercy except the lost?”*—resonates powerfully in today’s world, where despair often stems from systemic injustice, existential anxieties, and a fragmented sense of purpose. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, interpret this verse as a timeless reminder that hopelessness is a spiritual ailment rooted in disconnection from divine compassion. It is not merely an emotional state but a cognitive distortion that blinds individuals to the transformative potential of Allah’s mercy, which encompasses both personal redemption and collective healing.  

Modern psychology echoes this wisdom: studies on resilience affirm that hope is a survival mechanism, enabling humans to navigate adversity. The verse’s condemnation of despair aligns with therapeutic approaches that emphasize reframing challenges as opportunities for growth. For instance, psychologist Martin Seligman’s work on “learned optimism” mirrors the Qur’anic call to reject fatalism and cultivate trust in a higher purpose.  

Socially, this verse speaks to marginalized communities grappling with oppression or poverty. Scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim highlights how Shia theology frames resistance to injustice as an act of *tawakkul* (trust in God), urging activists to channel despair into constructive struggle. In contexts like climate crises or global conflicts, the verse challenges us to view ethical action—such as environmental stewardship or peacebuilding—as expressions of faith in divine mercy.  

Interfaith dialogue enriches this perspective: Buddhist teachings on *dukkha* (suffering) and Christian notions of grace similarly reject nihilism, fostering solidarity across traditions. In multicultural societies, this verse invites collaboration to address shared struggles, from mental health crises to socioeconomic inequities.  

Ultimately, 15:56 is a manifesto for hope. It rejects passive resignation, urging believers—and all humanity—to anchor themselves in the certainty that mercy transcends despair, guiding us toward justice, healing, and unity.
56.layer4:
The verse's profound declaration by Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) exposes despair in divine mercy as a hallmark of spiritual deviation. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) amplify this truth, teaching that hope in Allah’s boundless compassion is inseparable from faith itself. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, *“The most beloved deeds to Allah are hope in His mercy and certainty in His relief.”* This aligns with the verse’s censure of despair, framing hope as a sacred act of recognizing Allah’s infinite grace, which flows through the channels of divine guidance: the Imams of the Ahlul Bayt.  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) elucidates, *“Whoever despairs of Allah’s mercy has denied the vastness of His forgiveness, and whoever denies this has rejected the Imams, for we are the doors to His mercy.”* Here, the Imam ties hope directly to *Wilayah* – the divine guardianship of the infallible guides. To turn away from their intercession is to sever oneself from the lifeline of mercy. The verse’s condemnation of despair thus becomes a call to cling to the Imams, whose very existence is a manifestation of Allah’s compassion.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) exemplifies unwavering hope amid trials. It is narrated that during her profound hardships, she would say, *“O Allah! My reliance is on Your mercy. Do not abandon me to my despair, for in Your remembrance is my solace.”* Her words teach that hope is sustained through conscious remembrance (*dhikr*) and trust (*tawakkul*), even when circumstances seem bleak.  

Practically, the Ahlul Bayt urge believers to anchor hope through specific spiritual practices: supplicating at dawn (*sahar*), seeking forgiveness (*istighfar*), and invoking blessings upon the Prophet and his family (*salawat*). Imam Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) writes in the *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya*, *“O Allah! Let me not be among those who lose hope in Your relief, for You answer the distressed when they call.”*  

True hope, in the Shia tradition, is not passive optimism but active alignment with the Imams’ teachings. It means internalizing that Allah’s mercy transcends human error, and that the gates of repentance remain open through the Imams’ intercession. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) reminds us, *“The one who repents is like the one who never sinned,”* for divine mercy outpaces all despair. To live by this truth is to walk the path of the guided, never the astray.

56.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hijr 15:56, both Shia and Sunni scholars emphasize the Quranic condemnation of despairing from divine mercy as a hallmark of spiritual misguidance. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) concur that Prophet Ibrahim’s rhetorical question underscores the irrationality of losing hope in Allah’s compassion, with Al-Tabari highlighting this as a universal moral lesson and Al-Tabrisi linking it to the necessity of unwavering trust in divine promises. Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) both contextualize the verse within Ibrahim’s narrative, noting that despair contradicts prophetic wisdom and reflects a failure to recognize Allah’s omnipotence.  

Divergences emerge in theological implications. Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi frame despair (qunut) as a rejection of Allah’s all-encompassing mercy, often tying it to deviations in creed (aqida) or neglect of divine omnipotence. Shia exegetes, particularly Al-Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, expand this to include rejection of divinely appointed guidance (the Imams), interpreting “those astray” as those who oppose the Ahl al-Bayt’s spiritual authority. Al-Qummi’s tafsir reinforces this by citing traditions where despair is equated with denying the Imams’ intercessory role.  

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni interpretations prioritize Allah’s absolute power and human accountability, while Shia readings integrate Imamah into the ontology of divine mercy. Practically, this influences devotional practices, with Shia theology emphasizing recourse to the Imams for spiritual hope, whereas Sunni teachings focus on direct divine reliance. Historically, these interpretations reflect early theological debates on authority post-Prophet Muhammad, with Shia scholars grounding their views in the Prophet’s household’s legacy and Sunni scholars prioritizing scriptural and communal consensus. Both traditions, however, unite in urging believers to cultivate hope as an antidote to spiritual deviation.

57.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr, verse 15:57, Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) asks the divine messengers, *“Fama khatbukum ayyuha al-mursalun”*—“What is your mission, O messengers?” This question arises after Ibrahim, known for his unwavering hospitality, welcomes three angelic guests who first bring him news of his future son, Isaac. Sensing their visit held deeper significance, Ibrahim inquires further, demonstrating his wisdom and attentiveness to divine purpose. The term *khatb* here refers to a weighty matter or mission, while *mursalun* denotes messengers entrusted with a sacred task from Allah.  

This verse is set within the broader narrative of Ibrahim’s prophetic life, where his role as a leader and his concern for truth shine through. After receiving glad tidings, he recognizes the angels’ dual purpose: to also announce the impending judgment on the people of Lut (Lot). His inquiry reflects his deep sense of responsibility—not just for his family, but for the broader community. For believers today, this moment underscores the importance of seeking clarity in our spiritual and worldly affairs. Like Ibrahim, Muslims are encouraged to actively engage with life’s challenges through thoughtful questioning and trust in divine wisdom.  

In modern contexts, this teaches us to balance hospitality and compassion with critical thinking—whether in understanding religious obligations, addressing community issues, or navigating personal trials. The verse also reminds us to remain attuned to the “missions” Allah places in our lives, whether through acts of service, advocating justice, or nurturing faith. As emphasized in Shia teachings, following the example of the Ahlul Bayt, we are called to pursue knowledge, discern truth, and act with intention, ensuring our actions align with higher principles. Ibrahim’s dialogue with the angels is a timeless lesson in humility, curiosity, and trusting Allah’s plan even when His wisdom unfolds gradually.
57.layer2:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:57), Prophet Ibrahim’s inquiry to the divine messengers—“Then what is your business [here], O messengers?”—invites profound theological reflection within Shia exegesis. Classical commentators emphasize that Ibrahim’s question arises not from ignorance but from his prophetic insight into the angels’ multifaceted mission. While the immediate context pertains to their dual purpose—delivering glad tidings of Isaac’s birth (15:53-55) and proceeding to punish the people of Lut (15:58-60)—Shia scholars such as Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* interpret Ibrahim’s inquiry as a demonstration of his awareness of divine wisdom’s layered manifestations. His address, “O messengers,” acknowledges their sanctified status as bearers of Allah’s commands, reflecting the Shia theological principle that prophets inherently recognize celestial beings and their roles (Tabatabai, *Al-Mizan*, 12:159).

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, underscores the term *khatbukum* (“your business”) as indicative of a weighty divine decree, highlighting Ibrahim’s attunement to the gravity of their mission beyond his personal context. This aligns with the Shia view of prophets’ *ismah* (infallibility), wherein their questions or actions never stem from doubt but serve pedagogical or revelatory purposes. Here, Ibrahim’s query becomes a conduit for unveiling the impending judgment on Lut’s people, reinforcing the Quranic theme of divine justice intertwined with mercy—a concept central to Shia theodicy.

Theologically, this verse exemplifies the interplay between prophetic consciousness and divine communication. Shia commentaries often link such narratives to the Imams’ inherited knowledge (*ilm al-wilayah*), wherein the Ahl al-Bayt, as spiritual heirs to the prophets, embody similar discernment of hidden truths. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, in traditions cited by later exegetes, is reported to have elucidated that prophets and Imams perceive “the realities of matters” through divine illumination (*nur*), transcending literal appearances.

Jurisprudentially, the verse subtly underscores the principle of *tahqiq al-amr* (verifying matters), encouraging believers to seek clarity in divine commandments while maintaining reverence for divine agents. This resonates with Shia ethics, which advocate active engagement with revelation while upholding the hierarchy of spiritual authority. Ultimately, Ibrahim’s dialogue with the messengers epitomizes the Quranic synthesis of human inquiry and divine guidance—a cornerstone of Shia theological and hermeneutical tradition.
57.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:57), Prophet Ibrahim’s question to the divine messengers – “Then what is your business here, O messengers?” – resonates as a timeless model of intellectual engagement and spiritual vigilance. Contemporary Shia scholars, like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, emphasize that Ibrahim’s inquiry reflects the Quranic principle of *tahqiq* (critical verification), urging believers to actively seek truth rather than passively accept appearances. This aligns with the Shia theological emphasis on *‘aql* (intellect) as a divine gift, a theme echoed by scholars such as Sayyed Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, who framed questioning as a form of worship when rooted in sincerity.  

Modern applications emerge in contexts where discernment is vital: climate crises demand understanding humanity’s role as *khalifa* (stewards) of Earth, requiring us to “interrogate” both scientific data and ethical responsibilities. Socially, the verse invites parallels to movements for justice, where marginalized communities rightly ask power structures, “What is your purpose here?” – challenging systemic inequities. Philosophically, Ibrahim’s dialogue mirrors contemporary interfaith efforts; his respectful yet probing stance models how diverse traditions can converse without compromising core values. Pope Francis’s emphasis on “encounter” in dialogue reflects this Abrahamic ethos.  

Scientifically, the verse’s theme of seeking clarity aligns with the empirical method. Astrophysicist Mehdi Golshani, a Shia scholar, notes that Quranic calls to investigate nature (e.g., 3:191) harmonize with scientific inquiry when guided by ethical purpose. Here, Ibrahim’s question becomes a metaphor for humanity’s quest to understand cosmic mysteries while anchoring exploration in humility.  

In an era of misinformation, this verse underscores the duty to distinguish truth from deception. As scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim observes, Shia Islam’s narrative has always valorized “sacred resistance” to oppression – a resistance that begins with asking courageous questions, much like Ibrahim confronting unknown messengers. His legacy reminds us that faith and critical thought are not adversaries but allies in navigating modern complexities.
57.layer4:
In this profound moment where Prophet Ibrahim (a) addresses the celestial visitors with "What is your business here, O messengers?", we witness a window into the reality of divine communication and the spiritual discernment of Allah's chosen guides. The Ahlul Bayt (a) teach us that every word in the Quran carries layers of illumination for those rooted in *ma'rifah* (divine recognition). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (a) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi* that Ibrahim's question reveals the principle of *ta'yid* (divine strengthening) granted to prophets and their successors: "The Friends of Allah see with the Light of their Lord, recognizing angels even in human form, just as Ibrahim knew these were no ordinary guests."

This verse underscores the Shia understanding of *Wilayah* as the axis of cosmic truth. Lady Fatimah (a) declared in her famed sermon: "Allah made obedience to us the system for the community and our leadership (*Imamah*) a safeguard against disunity." The "business" of these messengers was not merely to announce the destruction of Lut's people, but to reaffirm the uninterrupted chain of divine guidance that would culminate in the Seal of Successors, Imam al-Mahdi (aj). Prophet Muhammad (s) said, "I and Ali are from one Light," reminding us that recognizing true messengers is inseparable from recognizing the purified Household who carry the Muhammadan Light.

Practically, this verse teaches believers to cultivate three spiritual qualities:  
1) **Attentiveness to Divine Signs**: As Imam Ali (a) advised, "The believer sees with the light of Allah," requiring us to purify our hearts through Quranic reflection and adherence to the Thaqalayn (Quran and Ahlul Bayt).  
2) **Respect for All Bearers of Truth**: The angels' humble appearance as travelers mirrors how divine wisdom often comes through unexpected channels. Imam Zain al-Abideen (a) taught, "The scholar who acts upon his knowledge is like the full moon among stars."  
3) **Alignment with the Purpose of Messengers**: Their ultimate mission was to establish divine justice - the very essence of awaiting Imam Mahdi's (aj) reappearance. 

Let us ask ourselves: Do we approach life with Ibrahim's clarity, discerning Allah's messengers in every era? Do we honor the "business" of the Ahlul Bayt's followers who uphold truth today? As we recite this verse, may it ignite in us the courage to say with Imam Hussain (a): "I see nothing but beauty in truth.

57.layer5:
The verse occurs within Abraham’s encounter with divine messengers announcing both Isaac’s birth and the impending destruction of Lot’s people. Both Sunni and Shia exegetes agree on the narrative context: Abraham’s initial uncertainty about his guests’ purpose transitions to understanding their dual mission (consensus in Tabari, Ibn Kathir, Al-Mizan, Majma al-Bayan). Scholars across traditions emphasize Abraham’s exemplary hospitality and his perceptive inquiry, reflecting prophetic wisdom in discerning divine intent.  

A key convergence lies in interpreting the messengers as angels, with Sunni sources like Qurtubi and Shia works such as Tafsir al-Qummi affirming their angelic nature. Both traditions also highlight Abraham’s humility; his question (“What is your business?”) underscores a prophet’s duty to seek clarity in divine communication (noted by Razi and Tabrisi).  

Interpretive differences emerge in theological underpinnings. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir focus on the *literal narrative*, framing Abraham’s inquiry as a natural response to unexpected guests, stressing human-prophet interaction with angels. In contrast, Shia exegesis, particularly in Al-Mizan, delves into *esoteric dimensions*: Tabatabai posits Abraham’s question reflects his awareness of angels’ hierarchical roles, informed by the *ilm al-ladunni* (divinely bestowed knowledge) associated with the Ahl al-Bayt. Tusi’s At-Tibyan further links this to the Shia emphasis on the necessity of infallible guides (Imams) to decode divine mysteries.  

Historically, these divergences stem from distinct hermeneutical priorities. Sunni tafsir often prioritizes transmitted reports (*riwaya*) and linguistic analysis, while Shia scholarship integrates transmitted traditions with theologically driven *ta’wil* (esoteric interpretation), rooted in the belief in the Imams’ inherited knowledge.  

Though these differences reflect theological frameworks, they seldom impact practical worship. Both traditions revere Abraham’s model of devotion, yet Shia interpretations may reinforce the concept of ongoing divine guidance through the Imamate, whereas Sunni readings emphasize prophetic precedent. Such nuances illustrate how shared scriptural foundations yield rich, complementary insights within Islam’s exegetical mosaic.
