تبتابائی ، *المزان *میں ، واضح ثبوتوں کے ذریعہ انسانی تنازعہ کو حل کرنے کے لئے الہی مداخلت کے قرآنی شکل میں آیت کو تیار کرکے اس تصور کو وسعت دیتے ہیں۔ فرشتوں کا اعلامیہ اخلاقی رشتہ داری کے خاتمے اور * حق * (سچ) پر فتح * بٹیل * (باطل) کے مقابلے میں ، جو شیعہ استثنیٰ میں ایک مرکزی خیال ہے ، کی علامت ہے۔ اس آیت میں نبیوں کے کردار کی نشاندہی کی گئی ہے جیسا کہ الہی رہنماؤں کی حیثیت سے معاشرتی بدعنوانی کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے ، خاص طور پر قدرتی اخلاقی نظم کی توثیق - لوگوں کی سرکشی کے ذریعہ یہاں مثال کے طور پر۔ شیعہ سوچ نے اس بات پر زور دیا ہے کہ اس طرح کے بیانیے انسانی انحراف کے درمیان سچائی کو محفوظ رکھنے اور واضح کرنے کے لئے الہی مقرر کردہ قیادت (امامیٹ) کی ضرورت کے لئے ایک مثال قائم کرتے ہیں۔  

مذہبی طور پر ، آیت * لوٹف * (خدائی فضل) کے اصول کو بھی اجاگر کرتی ہے ، جس میں خدا انسانیت کی رہنمائی کے لئے نشانات اور میسینجر بھیجتا ہے ، یہاں تک کہ جب انسانی انتخاب ان کی قسمت کا تعین کرتے ہیں۔ فقہی طور پر ، LUT کے لوگوں کا فنا مستقل گناہ کے سنگین نتائج اور اخلاقی اصولوں کو مسترد کرنے کے سنگین مثال کے طور پر کام کرتا ہے ، اور غیر اخلاقی طرز عمل کے خلاف اسلامی قانونی احکامات کو تقویت بخشتا ہے۔ شیخ توسی جیسے کلاسیکی اسکالرز نوٹ کرتے ہیں کہ یہ اکاؤنٹ شیعہ روحانیت کا مرکزیت کا مرکز ہے۔ ان پرتوں کے ذریعہ ، آیت شیعہ ورلڈ ویو کا ایک مائکروکومسم بن جاتی ہے: سچائی ، اگرچہ اس کا مقابلہ کیا گیا ہے ، بالآخر الہی مرضی سے ثابت ہوتا ہے ، اور نیک لوگوں کو بدعنوان سے ہمیشہ کے لئے ممتاز کیا جاتا ہے۔
63.layer3_urdu:
سورہ الہجر (15:63) میں ، فرشتوں کا ’’ ہم آپ کو جس چیز کے بارے میں متنازعہ بناتے ہیں اس کے بارے میں ہم آپ کو لاتے ہیں۔ عصر حاضر کے شیعہ اسکالرز ، جیسے آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ یہ آیت انسانی شکوک و شبہات کے درمیان الہی وضاحت کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے۔ یہاں "تنازعہ" محض تاریخی نہیں ہے بلکہ اخلاقی اعتقاد اور نسبت پسندی کے مابین انسانیت کی بارہماسی جدوجہد کی علامت ہے۔ فرشتوں کی قطعی سچائی کے ساتھ آمد قرآنی اصول کی آئینہ دار ہے جس سے الہی رہنمائی معاشرتی الجھن کو حل کرتی ہے ، جو انصاف میں ثابت قدمی سے متعلق احلول بیت کی تعلیمات میں گونجتی ہے۔

جدید ایپلی کیشنز آب و ہوا سے انکار ، سیسٹیمیٹک عدم مساوات اور اخلاقی کٹاؤ کے بارے میں مباحثوں میں ابھرتی ہیں۔ آیت اس بات کی عکاسی کرتی ہے کہ آج معاشرے ، جیسے لوٹ کے لوگوں کی طرح ، اکثر پیشن گوئی کی انتباہات کو مسترد کرتے ہیں - چاہے ماحولیاتی خاتمے یا معاشرتی ناانصافی کے بارے میں - محض "تنازعات" کے طور پر۔ سائنسی بصیرت ، جیسے کارپوریٹ لالچ سے ماحولیاتی انحطاط کو جوڑنے والے مطالعات ، اخلاقی غفلت میں جڑے ہوئے معاشرتی کشی کے قرآنی شکل کے متوازی۔ ماحولیاتی بحران ، جیسے LUT کی برادری کی تباہی ، اخلاقی خرابیوں کو نظرانداز کرنے کے ٹھوس نتائج کے طور پر کام کرتے ہیں۔

انٹرفیتھ ڈائیلاگ اس پیغام کو بڑھا دیتا ہے۔ جس طرح یہودی اور عیسائی روایات سدوم کی کہانی کو شریک کرتی ہیں ، جس میں اجتماعی ذمہ داری پر زور دیا گیا تھا ، شیعہ نے سوچا کہ اخلاقی ترک کرنے کے فطری نتائج کے استعارے کے طور پر خدائی سزا کو فریم کرتا ہے۔ کثیر الثقافتی معاشرے عالمگیر اسباق کو اپنی طرف متوجہ کرسکتے ہیں: اخلاقی وضاحت ثقافتی رشتہ داری کو عبور کرتی ہے ، اور سچائی سنانے-فرشتوں کے مشن کے مطابق-مشترکہ روحانی فرض ہے۔

اسکالر سید کمل الحیداری نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ عصری "تنازعات" اکثر طاقت کے عدم توازن کو نقاب پوش کرتے ہیں۔ اس طرح آیت معاشرتی انصاف کے شیعہ اصولوں کے ساتھ منسلک ، کمزوروں کے ساتھ یکجہتی پر زور دیتی ہے۔ غلط معلومات کے دور میں ، فرشتوں کے حقوق کے حامل کردار کو ہم نے انکار کرنے کا چیلنج کیا ہے ، چاہے وہ سیاست ، سائنس ، یا اخلاقیات میں ، اس خدائی حکمت کی تصدیق کر رہے ہیں-وجہ اور وحی کے ذریعہ انسانیت کو اپنے خود سے متاثر ہونے والے بحرانوں سے ماضی کی رہنمائی کرتے ہیں۔

لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے گہرے فداکیہ خطبہ میں ، اعلان کیا: "امام خدا کی بڑھتی ہوئی روشنی ، فیصلہ کن کلام اور رہنمائی ستارہ ہے۔" آسمانی میسینجرز کے ذریعہ تنازعات کو ختم کرنے کے اس آیت کا حوالہ شیعہ کو یہ سمجھنے کی پیش گوئی کرتا ہے کہ ہر دور میں اس کا ہجاہ (خدائی ثبوت) ہے - ایک ناقابل فہم رہنما جو ابہام کے اندھیرے کو دور کرتا ہے۔ جب کمیونٹیز سچ کی ترجمانی پر فریکچر کرتی ہیں تو ، اہل بیت الہی حکمت اور انسانی افہام و تفہیم کے ہم آہنگ کی حیثیت سے کھڑے ہیں۔

امام جعفر السادق (ع) نے سکھایا: "یقین (یاقین) پورا عقیدہ ہے۔" فرشتوں کا مشن ناقابل تسخیر سچائی کی فراہمی کے متوازی ہے کہ کس طرح اماموں نے مومنوں کے دلوں میں یاقین کی پرورش کی۔ جس طرح ابراہیم کے مہمانوں نے قطعی جوابات پیش کیے ، اسی طرح محمد کی اولاد کی تعلیمات آج مومنوں کو زندگی کے شبہات کے طوفانوں کے درمیان غیر متزلزل بنیادیں فراہم کرتی ہیں۔

عملی حکمت اس آیت کی روشنی سے بہتی ہے: جب فکری الجھن یا روحانی غیر یقینی صورتحال کا سامنا کرنا پڑتا ہے تو ، اماموں کی مستند تعلیمات کی طرف رجوع کریں جیسے آپ کے آسمانی زائرین قرارداد پر مشتمل ہیں۔ امام زین الیبدین (ع) کے صیفا سججدیہ سے دوہہ کی تلاوت کریں: "اے حیرت زدہ رہنمائی! اپنی رہنمائی کے ذریعہ میری رہنمائی کریں۔" اہل بیت کی تشریحات کے عینک کے ذریعہ قرآنی آیات کے ساتھ باقاعدگی سے مشغول رہیں ، جیسا کہ امام علی (ع) نے کہا ، "ہر آیت کے چار معنی ہیں" صرف الہی ہدایت یافتہ اساتذہ کے ذریعہ قابل رسائی ہیں۔ آپ کے روز مرہ کے روحانی مشق کو اپنے راستے کو روشن کرنے کے لئے اماموں کی شفاعت (تواسول) کی تلاش میں شامل ہونے دیں ، زندگی کے تنازعات کو محمدن روشنی کے ساتھ گہری رابطے کے مواقع میں تبدیل کریں۔
63.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hijr 15:63, both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly agree that the verse refers to angels informing Prophet Lut of the divine punishment awaiting his people, who persistently doubted his message. Classical commentators like Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia) concur that the "dispute" (yamtarūn) centers on the people’s rejection of Lut’s prophethood and their moral corruption, as noted in Majma al-Bayan and Jami al-Bayan. Ibn Kathir and Qummi both contextualize the verse within the narrative of divine retribution against persistent disbelief, reflecting shared Abrahamic themes of prophetic trials and communal accountability.

Divergent interpretations emerge regarding the nature of the "dispute." Sunni scholars such as Qurtubi and Razi emphasize the people’s skepticism toward Lut’s warnings as a rejection of clear prophetic signs, framing the verse as a lesson on the consequences of defying divine guidance. In contrast, Shia commentators like Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Tusi (At-Tibyan) extend the interpretation to encompass broader theological disputes over divine authority (wilāyah), drawing parallels to post-prophetic conflicts over legitimate leadership. Al-Qummi’s tafsir subtly links the verse to the necessity of divinely appointed guides resolving intellectual and spiritual ambiguities, reflecting the Shia emphasis on Imamah as a continuation of prophetic mission.

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis prioritizes historical-literary analysis of prophetic narratives, while Shia scholarship often integrates Imamah theology into Quranic hermeneutics. Such variations influence conceptions of religious authority but do not fundamentally conflict on the verse’s moral and eschatological message. Historically, these interpretive trajectories developed alongside theological debates in early Islam, with Shia scholars systematizing their approach during the Imamates of the Ahl al-Bayt, while Sunni tafsir traditions crystallized through hadith-centric methodologies. Both traditions ultimately affirm the Quranic principle that divine truth resolves human contention.

"تنازعہ" کی نوعیت کے حوالے سے مختلف تشریحات ابھرتی ہیں۔ سنی اسکالرز جیسے قربانی اور ریزی نے واضح پیشن گوئی کی علامتوں کو مسترد کرتے ہوئے ، لوٹ کی انتباہات کے بارے میں لوگوں کے شکوک و شبہات پر زور دیا ہے ، اور اس آیت کو خدائی رہنمائی سے انکار کرنے کے نتائج پر سبق کے طور پر تیار کیا ہے۔ اس کے برعکس ، تبتابائی (المزان) اور توسی (ایٹ تبیان) جیسے شیعہ مبصرین الہی اتھارٹی (ولیہ) کے بارے میں وسیع تر مذہبی تنازعات کو گھیرنے کی تشریح میں توسیع کرتے ہیں ، اور جائز قیادت پر بعد ازاں تنازعات کے متوازی ہوتے ہیں۔ القومی کا طافسر اس آیت کو پوری طرح سے الہی مقرر کردہ رہنماؤں کی ضرورت سے جوڑتا ہے جو دانشورانہ اور روحانی ابہام کو حل کرتے ہیں ، جو پیشن گوئی کے مشن کے تسلسل کے طور پر امامہ پر شیعہ پر زور دینے کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔

یہ اختلافات الگ الگ مذہبی فریم ورک سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: سنی کی اصلاح پیشن گوئی کے بیانیے کے تاریخی لیٹرری تجزیہ کو ترجیح دیتی ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ اسکالرشپ اکثر امامہ الہیات کو قرآنی ہرمینیٹکس میں ضم کرتا ہے۔ اس طرح کی تغیرات مذہبی اتھارٹی کے تصورات کو متاثر کرتی ہیں لیکن اس آیت کے اخلاقی اور شعوری پیغام پر بنیادی طور پر متصادم نہیں ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، ابتدائی اسلام میں مذہبی مباحثوں کے ساتھ ساتھ یہ تشریحی رفتار تیار ہوئی ، شیعہ اسکالرز نے اہل البیٹ کے امامیٹ کے دوران اپنے نقطہ نظر کو منظم کیا ، جبکہ سنی طافسیر روایات حدیث پر مبنی طریقہ کار کے ذریعہ کرسٹل بناتی ہیں۔ دونوں روایات بالآخر قرآنی اصول کی تصدیق کرتی ہیں کہ خدائی سچائی انسانی تنازعہ کو حل کرتی ہے۔

64.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:64), the angels address Prophet Lut (Lot) as they arrive to deliver divine command and warning before the destruction of his corrupt people. The verse, *"And we have come to you with truth, and indeed, we are truthful,"* underscores the absolute certainty and divine origin of their message. Here, the term *al-haqq* (الحق) signifies both "truth" and "reality," reflecting the inseparable link between divine revelation and objective reality. The angels’ declaration *"inna la-sadiqoon"* (إِنَّا لَصَٰدِقُونَ) emphasizes their unwavering truthfulness, reinforcing the trustworthiness of Allah’s messengers and His plan even in moments of trial.  

Historically, this verse emerges as Lut’s people persist in immoral acts, rejecting his calls to righteousness. The angels’ arrival marks both a test of faith for Lut’s family and a final mercy before inevitable divine justice. Their assurance of *al-haqq* serves to strengthen Lut’s resolve, affirming that divine truth transcends human denial.  

Key terms like *al-haqq* remind believers that Islam’s teachings are rooted in eternal truths, not subjective opinions. The angels’ identity as *sadiqoon* (truthful ones) sets a standard for Muslims: truthfulness in word and action is a divine attribute to embody. Today, this verse calls Muslims to align their lives with *al-haqq*—rejecting moral relativism, standing firm in ethical principles despite societal pressures, and trusting Allah’s wisdom even when outcomes seem delayed or unclear.  

Practically, this means seeking knowledge grounded in Quranic truth, speaking honestly in personal and communal matters, and maintaining faith during trials, knowing Allah’s promises are *sadiq* (truthful). As the angels supported Lut with unshakable certainty, Muslims today are reminded to anchor their lives in divine truth, confident that sincerity and adherence to *al-haqq* will ultimately prevail, no matter the challenges.
64.layer2:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:64), the divine messengers address Prophet Lut, affirming the truthfulness of their mission: *“And we have come to you with truth, and indeed, we are truthful.”* Classical Shia exegesis, as articulated in sources like Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, interprets this verse as a profound assertion of divine authority and the unerring nature of revelation. The angels’ declaration underscores the ontological connection between divine command (*amr*) and its manifestation through chosen intermediaries, a theme central to Shia theology. 

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasizes that the phrase *“we have come to you with truth”* signifies the angels’ role as bearers of *haqq*—a term denoting both factual truth and divine reality. This aligns with the Shia understanding of prophetic and Imamic missions, wherein divine guidance (*hidayah*) is transmitted through infallible channels. The angels’ emphasis on their own truthfulness (*inna la-sadiqun*) reinforces the theological principle of *ismah* (infallibility), a quality extended to the Prophets and Imams in Shia doctrine. Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, situates this verse within the broader Quranic discourse on the certainty of divine promise, arguing that the “truth” here encompasses both the immediate warning of punishment for Lut’s people and the eternal reality of God’s justice. 

Shia commentators also draw parallels between this verse and the role of the Ahl al-Bayt as inheritors of prophetic truth. Just as the angels affirm their message’s authenticity, the Imams—as articulated in traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq—are regarded as custodians of *al-haqq*, preserving and explicating divine revelation. The verse thus implicitly validates the concept of *wilayah* (divinely ordained authority), a cornerstone of Shia jurisprudence and creed. 

Theologically, the verse reaffirms the inseparability of divine truth from its bearers, a principle reflected in Shia epistemology. Acceptance of such truth is not merely intellectual but entails submission to God’s chosen guides, a theme resonating in Shia ritual and ethical practice. In this light, the verse transcends its historical context, serving as a perpetual reminder of the unbroken chain of divine guidance culminating in the Imamate.
64.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:64), the divine messengers assure Prophet Lut (Lot) of their truthful mission, stating, *“We have come to you with truth, and indeed, we are truthful.”* Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Jawadi Amuli and Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi, interpret this verse as a reaffirmation of Islam’s core principle: divine truth (haqq) as an unshakeable foundation amid societal chaos. The verse underscores the role of revelation in grounding human understanding beyond subjective biases—a concept profoundly relevant today, where misinformation and ideological polarization dominate public discourse.

Modern scholars like Sayyed Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah emphasize that this “truth” extends beyond mere factual accuracy; it encompasses ethical clarity and spiritual integrity. In an era of “post-truth” politics and algorithmic echo chambers, the verse challenges believers to align their actions with transcendent principles, resisting relativism. Philosophically, this aligns with Hannah Arendt’s critique of “truth decay” in societies that prioritize expediency over morality. The angels’ declaration here serves as a metaphor for the responsibility of religious and intellectual leaders to uphold integrity, even when truths are inconvenient.

Scientifically, the verse invites reflection on the harmony between empirical inquiry and divine wisdom. Physicist and theologian Mehdi Golshani notes that the Quranic concept of haqq resonates with the scientific pursuit of objective reality—both require humility before truths larger than human constructs. Socially, the verse critiques systems built on deception, such as exploitative capitalism or environmental denialism, urging a return to accountability. Climate activists, for instance, echo the angels’ mission by demanding acknowledgment of ecological truths.

Interfaith perspectives highlight shared values: the Jewish pursuit of *emet* (truth), the Christian “way, truth, and life” (John 14:6), and the Islamic haqq all converge on truth as sacred. In multicultural societies, this verse becomes a call to foster dialogue rooted in mutual respect for objective ethical standards. As global crises—from inequality to AI ethics—demand collective solutions, Surah Al-Hijr’s timeless message reminds humanity that progress requires anchoring innovation in timeless, life-affirming truths.
64.layer4:
divine declaration in Surah Al-Hijr (15:64), *“And we have come to you with truth, and indeed, we are truthful,”* resonates as an eternal testament to the unbroken chain of heavenly guidance embodied in the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). When the angels proclaimed this truth to Prophet Lut (as), they affirmed the certainty of divine promise—a principle that finds its fullest expression in the Wilayah (divine guardianship) of the Imams from the Prophet’s purified progeny. The “truth” (haqq) they carried is not merely information but the living reality of guidance preserved through the successors of the Final Prophet (pbuh).  

Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (as) taught, *“We are the Truth and its bearers, the lanterns of guidance, and the pillars of divine light. Whoever holds fast to us will never stray.”* This hadith illuminates the verse’s essence: the Ahlul Bayt are the embodiment and custodians of the Quranic truth, safeguarding its meanings from distortion. Just as the angels brought certainty to Lut, the Imams dispel doubt and illuminate the path for their followers. Lady Fatimah (as) encapsulated this in her timeless sermon: *“Allah made obedience to us the foundation of His religion and our Wilayah the fortress of His wisdom.”* Her words remind us that recognizing the Ahlul Bayt’s station is inseparable from upholding truth itself.  

The spiritual depth of this verse calls believers to internalize two realities: **certainty** (yaqeen) and **submission** (tasleem). Imam Ali (as) said, *“Truth is heavy on the tongue but light in the heart of the faithful.”* To embody truthfulness, one must align speech, action, and intention with the teachings of the Imams, who are the “speaking Quran.” Practically, this demands seeking knowledge through their narrations, reflecting on their supplications (like Sahifa Sajjadiyah), and cultivating sincerity in worship.  

The verse also underscores the Shia concept of Imamah—a divine covenant ensuring the continuity of truth. As the angels declared their mission with authority, the Imams’ divine appointment at Ghadeer Khumm confirms their role as infallible guides. To walk this path is to embrace Imam al-Baqir’s (as) counsel: *“Hold firm to the rope of Wilayah, for it is the covenant of Allah that He entrusted to His creation.”*  

In moments of doubt or trial, remember: the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings are the unwavering truth. Let their example inspire you to speak justice, act with integrity, and anchor your soul in the love of those whom Allah purified—the ultimate manifestation of His truthful promise.

امام جافر السادق (ع) نے سکھایا ، * "ہم سچائی اور اس کے اٹھانے والے ، رہنمائی کے لالٹے ہیں ، اور خدائی روشنی کے ستون ہیں۔ جو بھی ہمارے پاس روزہ رکھے ہوئے ہے وہ کبھی نہیں بھٹکتے ہیں۔" * یہ حدیث اس کے جوہر کو روشن کرتا ہے: اس کا مطلب یہ ہے کہ اس کا مطلب یہ ہے۔ جس طرح فرشتوں نے LUT کو یقین دلایا ، اسی طرح اماموں نے شکوک و شبہات کو دور کیا اور اپنے پیروکاروں کے لئے راستہ روشن کیا۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے لازوال خطبے میں اس کی تائید کی: * "اللہ نے ہمارے مذہب کی بنیاد اور ہمارے ویلیح کو اپنی حکمت کا قلعہ بنا دیا۔"  

اس آیت کی روحانی گہرائی مومنوں کو دو حقائق کو اندرونی بنانے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے: ** یقین ** (یاقین) اور ** جمع کرانے ** (تاسلیم)۔ امام علی (ع) نے کہا ، * "حقیقت زبان پر بھاری ہے لیکن وفاداروں کے دل میں روشنی ہے۔" عملی طور پر ، یہ ان کی روایات کے ذریعہ علم کے حصول کا مطالبہ کرتا ہے ، ان کی فراہمی (جیسے ساہفا سججدیہ) پر غور کرتا ہے ، اور عبادت میں اخلاص کاشت کرتا ہے۔  

اس آیت میں امامہ کے شیعہ تصور کی بھی نشاندہی کی گئی ہے۔ یہ ایک الہی عہد ہے جو سچائی کے تسلسل کو یقینی بناتا ہے۔ چونکہ فرشتوں نے اختیار کے ساتھ اپنے مشن کا اعلان کیا ، گڈیر خمم میں اماموں کی الہی تقرری نے ان کے قابل رہنماؤں کے طور پر ان کے کردار کی تصدیق کی ہے۔ اس راستے پر چلنے کے لئے امام البقیر (ع) کے مشورے کو گلے لگانا ہے: *"ولیہ کی رسی پر فائز رہیں ، کیونکہ یہ اللہ کا عہد ہے جسے اس نے اپنی تخلیق کو سونپا تھا۔" *  

شکوک و شبہات یا مقدمے کی سماعت کے لمحات میں ، یاد رکھیں: اہل بیت کی تعلیمات غیر متزلزل حقیقت ہیں۔ ان کی مثال آپ کو انصاف بولنے ، سالمیت کے ساتھ کام کرنے ، اور اپنی روح کو ان لوگوں کی محبت میں لنگر انداز کرنے کی ترغیب دیتی ہے جن کو اللہ نے پاک کیا تھا۔
64.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hijr 15:64, both Shia and Sunni scholarly traditions converge on the verse’s immediate context: the angels’ assurance to Prophet Lut (Lot) of the impending divine punishment for his people, emphasizing the certainty and truthfulness of their message. Classical exegetes like Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) in *Majma al-Bayan* agree the verse underscores Allah’s absolute truthfulness in fulfilling warnings and promises, reflecting a shared theological principle of divine justice. Ibn Kathir and Al-Qummi both contextualize the verse within the broader Quranic theme of prophetic missions facing societal rejection, highlighting the angels’ role as divine agents of truth.

Divergent interpretations emerge in theological implications. Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi focus on the historical-legal dimensions, interpreting “the truth” (*al-haqq*) as the specific decree of punishment. Al-Tabari stresses the angels’ literal truthfulness, aligning with Sunni emphasis on Allah’s *khabar* (informational truth) as binding. Shia scholars, particularly Al-Tabtabai in *Al-Mizan*, extend “the truth” to encompass metaphysical realities, including the continuity of divine guidance through the Imamate. Al-Tusi’s *Al-Tibyan* and Al-Qummi’s tafsir link the verse to the necessity of unwavering trust in divinely appointed authorities, reflecting the Shia theological framework of *wilayah* (divine guardianship).

These differences stem from distinct hermeneutical priorities: Sunni exegesis often prioritizes textual-historical analysis, while Shia tafsir integrates the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt as interpretive authorities. Practically, this influences Shia emphasis on the Imam’s infallible guidance versus Sunni focus on communal adherence to revealed texts. Historically, these divergences arose from early theological debates over leadership and interpretive authority post-Prophet Muhammad, crystallizing into distinct exegetical methodologies. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s core message: divine truth transcends human skepticism, demanding submission to Allah’s decree.

سورہ الہجر 15:64 کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، شیعہ اور سنی علمی روایات آیت کے فوری سیاق و سباق پر ایک دوسرے کے ساتھ مل جاتی ہیں: فرشتوں کو اپنے لوگوں کے لئے آنے والے الہی سزا کی نبی lot لوٹ (لاٹ) کی یقین دہانی ، ان کے پیغام کی یقین دہانی اور سچائی پر زور دیتے ہوئے۔ طبقاتی استثنیٰ جیسے التاباری (سنی) اور الاتبریسی (شیعہ) * ماجما البیان * میں اس بات پر متفق ہیں کہ آیت انتباہات اور وعدوں کو پورا کرنے میں اللہ کی مطلق سچائی کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے ، جو الہی انصاف کے مشترکہ مذہبی اصول کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔ ابن کتھیر اور القومی دونوں معاشرتی مسترد ہونے کا سامنا کرنے والے پیشن گوئی مشنوں کے وسیع تر قرآنی موضوع کے اندر آیت کو سیاق و سباق دیتے ہیں ، اور فرشتوں کے حق کے الہی ایجنٹوں کے کردار کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں۔

مذہبی مضمرات میں مختلف تشریحات ابھرتی ہیں۔ سنی مبصرین جیسے القورووبی اور الراجی تاریخی قانونی جہتوں پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں ، اور "سچائی" (*الحق*) کو سزا کے مخصوص فرمان کے طور پر ترجمانی کرتے ہیں۔ التباری فرشتوں کی لفظی سچائی پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اور اللہ کے * خابر * (معلوماتی سچائی) پر سنی زور کے ساتھ جکڑے ہوئے ہیں۔ شیعہ اسکالرز ، خاص طور پر *المزان *میں الاتبٹابائی ، "سچائی" کو بڑھا دیتے ہیں تاکہ استعاریاتی حقائق کو گھیرے میں ، جس میں امامیٹ کے ذریعہ الہی رہنمائی کا تسلسل بھی شامل ہے۔ التوسی کا * الی تیبیان * اور القومی کے طافسر آیت کو الہی مقرر کردہ حکام میں غیر متزلزل اعتماد کی ضرورت سے جوڑتے ہیں ، جو * ولیہ * (الہی سرپرستی) کے شیعہ مذہبی فریم ورک کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔

یہ اختلافات الگ الگ ہرمینیٹیکل ترجیحات سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: سنی استثنیٰ اکثر متنی-تاریخی تجزیہ کو ترجیح دیتا ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ طافسیر اے ایچ ایل البیٹ کی تعلیمات کو تشریحی حکام کے طور پر مربوط کرتا ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، اس سے شیعہ کو امام کی ناقابل تسخیر رہنمائی پر زور دینے پر اثر پڑتا ہے بمقابلہ سنی نے انکشاف کردہ متن پر فرقہ وارانہ عمل پر توجہ مرکوز کی۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ تغیرات قیادت اور تشریحی اتھارٹی کے بعد ابتدائی مذہبی مباحثوں سے پیدا ہوئے ہیں ، جو پروفیوٹ کے بعد محمد ، واضح طور پر الگ الگ طریقہ کار میں شامل ہیں۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کے بنیادی پیغام کو برقرار رکھتی ہیں: الہی سچائی انسانی شکوک و شبہات سے بالاتر ہے ، اور اللہ کے فرمان کو پیش کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔

65.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:65), Allah commands Prophet Lut (Lot) to leave the sinful city of Sodom under the cover of night, guiding his family to safety before divine punishment strikes. The verse urges: *“Fa asri bi-ahlika biqt’in min al-layl…”* (“So set out with your family during a portion of the night…”). Here, *asri* (set out) emphasizes urgency and secrecy, while *biqt’in min al-layl* (a portion of the night) highlights wisdom in choosing a time less likely to attract attention. The instruction *wa attabi’ adbarahum* (“and follow behind them”) signifies Lut’s role as protector, ensuring his family stays together. The warning *la yaltafit* (“let no one look back”) is a profound test of faith, prohibiting attachment to a corrupt society. The final command *wa-mdhu haythu tu’marun* (“continue to where you are commanded”) underscores absolute trust in divine guidance.

This verse reflects the moral collapse of Sodom, where Lut’s people rejected his call to abandon oppression and sexual immorality. When they threatened him, Allah ordered Lut’s escape as the final act of mercy. The prohibition against looking back—famously violated by Lut’s wife, who perished—symbolizes the danger of longing for a corrupt past. Classical scholars like Tabatabai note that *la yaltafit* warns against both physical glances and emotional ties to sin.

Today, this verse teaches Muslims to prioritize obedience to Allah over comfort, even when it demands leaving harmful environments or relationships. It encourages vigilance in protecting one’s family from spiritual harm and resisting nostalgia for toxic habits or spaces. The command to “continue” without hesitation reminds believers to trust Allah’s plan amid uncertainty, embodying the resilience taught by the Ahlul Bayt: moving forward in faith, not backward in doubt.
65.layer2:
In Surah al-Hijr 15:65, the divine command to Prophet Lut to depart Sodom under divine protection carries profound theological and ethical implications within Shia exegesis. Classical commentators such as Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasise that this verse encapsulates themes of divine guardianship (wilayah), unwavering obedience to God’s command, and the existential severance from moral corruption. The instruction to travel "during a portion of the night" is interpreted symbolically and literally: night signifies both the urgency of spiritual vigilance and the practical concealment from hostile forces, reflecting the Shia principle of *taqiyyah* (prudential dissimulation) when confronting oppression. 

Tabrisi notes that the phrase "follow behind them" underscores Lut’s role as the spiritual and physical protector of his faithful family, mirroring the Shia understanding of prophetic and Imamic leadership safeguarding the community. The prohibition against "looking back" transcends mere physical action; Tabatabai elucidates it as a rejection of attachment to a corrupt societal order, symbolising complete trust in divine decree. This aligns with the Shia theological axiom of *tawakkul* (reliance on God), requiring believers to abandon hesitation or nostalgia for falsehood once truth is embraced. 

The concluding command — "continue on to where you are commanded" — is tied by Shia scholars to the broader concept of *amr* (divine ordinance), resonating with the necessity of submitting to God’s will as mediated through prophetic and Imamic guidance. This verse thus prefigures the Shia doctrine of Imamate, where obedience to the *Ahl al-Bayt* becomes an extension of obedience to God’s command. Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the obligation to prioritise divine law over societal norms, a principle foundational to Shia ethics. The narrative of Lut’s departure, as exegetes highlight, serves as an eternal paradigm for believers navigating moral dissolution, affirming that salvation lies in unwavering adherence to divine instruction under rightful guidance.
65.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr 15:65, Prophet Lut is instructed to lead his family out under night’s cover, urging them not to look back as they heed divine command. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, frame this as a timeless metaphor for moral courage and decisive action in moments of societal decay. The verse underscores the necessity of leaving corrupt systems—whether ideological, environmental, or political—without nostalgia for harmful norms. Scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim highlights how this “exodus” narrative resonates with modern struggles, from refugees fleeing war to activists abandoning oppressive structures, emphasizing trust in divine wisdom amid uncertainty.

Scientifically, the command to depart at night aligns with strategic crisis management. Research on disaster response, like that cited by sociologist Dr. Kathleen Tierney, shows that survival often hinges on timely, collective movement—mirroring the urgency in Lut’s story. The prohibition against looking back finds echoes in psychology; Dr. Bessel van der Kolk’s work on trauma illustrates how fixation on past harm inhibits healing, urging forward-focused resilience.

Today, this verse speaks to climate migrants forced to abandon homes or communities resisting systemic injustices. It challenges leaders to prioritize ethical direction over complacency, akin to Imam Ali’s counsel in Nahj al-Balagha: “Do not be a slave to what has destroyed others.” Philosophically, it invites reflection on submission (islam) as active trust—a theme interfaith dialogues amplify. Jewish and Christian traditions share Lut’s narrative, fostering solidarity in addressing displacement and moral compromise. In multicultural societies, the story becomes a call to support those “fleeing” oppression, whether literal or metaphorical, while nurturing collective accountability.

Ultimately, the verse is a manifesto for audacious faith—not passive acceptance, but courageous movement toward justice, guided by divine light even in darkness. As contemporary mystic Seyyed Hossein Nasr observes, “To walk where commanded is to align one’s soul with the cosmic order of Rahman, step by step, into renewal.
65.layer4:
The command to Prophet Lut (as) in this verse carries profound spiritual symbolism illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as). When Allah (swt) orders, "*Let not anyone among you look back*," it reflects the necessity of complete submission (taslim) to divine will—a recurring theme in the lives of the Infallibles. Imam Ali (as) taught, "Certainty (yaqeen) is the fire that burns every doubt," emphasizing that spiritual progress requires undivided focus on Allah’s command, free from hesitation or longing for what lies behind.

The instruction to journey "*during a portion of the night*" holds layers of wisdom. Night symbolizes spiritual darkness and trials, where believers must rely on the light (nur) of guidance—embodied in the Imamah. The Ahlul Bayt (as) are described in hadith as "stars guiding travelers through darkness" (Imam Sadiq (as), Bihar al-Anwar). Just as Lut’s family was instructed to follow a divinely ordained path without deviation, Shia theology stresses that following the Imam’s wilayah is the safeguard against spiritual ruin. Lady Fatimah (sa) encapsulated this in her famous words: "Obeying us is order, and our wilayah is protection."

The prohibition against looking back mirrors the necessity to abandon attachment to worldly distractions. Imam Baqir (as) taught, "The believer’s heart is tied to nothing but his Lord," reminding us that spiritual ascent demands detachment (zuhd) from all that pulls one away from divine proximity. Prophet Lut’s wife, who disobeyed this command, serves as a cautionary tale against valuing worldly ties over obedience to Allah’s representatives.

Practically, this verse urges believers to:  
1. Embrace nocturnal spirituality—using the night for prayer, reflection, and seeking forgiveness, as the Imams emphasized.  
2. Cultulate unwavering trust in divine guidance, even when it contradicts personal desires.  
3. Avoid "spiritual backward glances"—dwelling on past sins, worldly regrets, or doubting Allah’s plan.  

Imam Sadiq (as) taught that trials are "polishers of the soul," and this verse exemplifies how obedience during hardship purifies the heart. By aligning our steps with the commanded path—symbolized by adherence to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings—we secure both temporal and eternal salvation. As Imam Ali (as) stated, "Whoever follows guidance will not be led astray," affirming that the straight path lies in holding fast to the Thaqalayn: the Quran and the Purified Household.

65.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hijr 15:65, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s core narrative: Prophet Lut’s (AS) divinely mandated departure from Sodom with his family, emphasizing obedience to God’s command and the prohibition against looking back. Classical Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir contextualize the command as a test of faith, with Ibn Kathir explicitly linking the prohibition on glancing backward to the fate of Lut’s wife, who disobeyed and was consequently destroyed (Tafsir Ibn Kathir). Similarly, Shia sources such as Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* affirm this narrative framework, stressing the necessity of complete submission to divine will as exemplified by the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on prophetic trials.

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Sunni scholars like Qurtubi and Razi often focus on the literal-historical dimensions, interpreting “let not anyone among you look back” as a physical prohibition tied to the imminent punishment of Sodom. In contrast, Shia exegetes such as Al-Qummi and Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) incorporate symbolic readings, viewing the command as an allegory for spiritual detachment from corruption. Tabatabai notably expands this to a broader ethical principle, arguing that “looking back” signifies lingering attachment to sinful environments, necessitating perpetual vigilance in faith—a perspective rooted in the Shia theological emphasis on the heart’s purity (Al-Mizan).

These differences reflect distinct hermeneutical priorities: Sunni tafsir often prioritizes textual literalism and prophetic precedent (sunnah), while Shia commentaries integrate the teachings of the Imams to derive layered meanings. Historically, such divergences arose from Shia scholars’ reliance on the Imams’ interpretive authority post-Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), whereas Sunni traditions consolidated around early community consensus and transmitted narrations. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s central lesson: unwavering obedience to divine command as the path to salvation.

مذہبی زور سے تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ سنی اسکالرز جیسے قربانی اور رازی اکثر لفظی تاریخی طول و عرض پر توجہ دیتے ہیں ، اور اس کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں کہ "آپ میں سے کسی کو پیچھے نہیں دیکھنے دیں" جسمانی ممانعت کے طور پر سدوم کی آسنن عذاب سے منسلک ہیں۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ الکوومی اور توسی (*ایٹ تبیان*) جیسے علامتی مطالعات کو شامل کرتے ہیں ، اور اس حکم کو بدعنوانی سے روحانی لاتعلقی کے لئے ایک نظریہ کے طور پر دیکھتے ہیں۔ تبتابائی خاص طور پر اس کو ایک وسیع تر اخلاقی اصول تک پھیلاتے ہیں ، اور یہ استدلال کرتے ہیں کہ "پیچھے مڑ کر" گنہگار ماحول سے منسلک منسلک ہونے کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جس سے عقیدے میں مستقل چوکسی کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔

یہ اختلافات الگ الگ ہرمینیٹیکل ترجیحات کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں: سنی طافسر اکثر متنی خواندہ اور پیشن گوئی کی نظیر (سنت) کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ تبصرے پرتوں کے معنی اخذ کرنے کے لئے اماموں کی تعلیمات کو مربوط کرتے ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، اس طرح کے تغیرات شیعہ اسکالرز کے ’اماموں‘ پر انحصار سے پیدا ہوئے ہیں ’’ تشریحی اتھارٹی کے بعد کے بعد کے حامی محمد (پی بی یو ایچ) ، جبکہ سنی روایات ابتدائی معاشرے کے اتفاق رائے اور منتقلی کی روایات کے گرد مستحکم ہیں۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کے مرکزی سبق کو برقرار رکھتی ہیں: نجات کی راہ کے طور پر الہی حکم کی غیر متزلزل اطاعت۔

66.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr verse 66, Allah addresses Prophet Lut (Lot), reassuring him of the divine decree to destroy his disbelieving people by morning. The verse uses the phrase *"wa qadayna ilayhi dhalika al-amr"* ("We conveyed to him that matter"), emphasizing Allah’s authority in deciding outcomes and His direct communication with His prophets. The term *qadayna* (We decreed) reflects finality, showing that divine judgment is inevitable once corruption exceeds all limits. The word *dabir* refers to the "root" or "last remnant" of something, signifying the complete eradication of the sinful community. The timing specified—*musbihina* (early morning)—highlights both the suddenness of divine punishment and the precision of Allah’s plan.

Historically, this verse relates to Lut’s people in Sodom, who rejected his calls to abandon their immoral practices, including widespread injustice and homosexuality. Allah’s warning through Lut—and its ultimate fulfillment—serves as a lesson about the consequences of persistent wrongdoing despite clear guidance. The phrase *"those sinners would be eliminated"* underscores that divine justice, though patient, cannot be evaded when societies institutionalize evil.

For modern Muslims, this verse reinforces three key principles: trust in Allah’s ultimate justice, the importance of heeding prophetic warnings (whether through scripture or righteous voices today), and the urgency of upholding moral boundaries collectively. It reminds us that societal corruption, when normalized and unchecked, invites spiritual and material collapse. Practically, this calls for actively opposing systemic oppression, promoting ethical norms with wisdom, and maintaining hope that truth will prevail, even if challenges persist. The dawn (*musbihina*) symbolizes both the darkness of heedlessness and the light of divine intervention—encouraging believers to align their efforts with truth before the "morning" of reckoning arrives.
66.layer2:
In interpreting Surah al-Hijr (15:66), classical Shia commentators emphasise both the ontological authority of divine decree (qadā) and the ethical framework of divine justice central to Shia theology. The verse’s phrasing – “We conveyed to him [Lut] that matter: that those [sinners] would be eliminated by early morning” – underscores God’s absolute sovereignty in executing judgment while simultaneously affirming the prophetic role as a recipient and communicator of divine will. As Tabatabai elucidates in *Al-Mizan*, the term “qadayna” (We decreed) denotes an irrevocable divine resolution, inseparable from God’s pre-eternal knowledge (‘ilm al-ghayb), yet enacted through temporal causation within creation’s framework. This aligns with the Shia doctrinal balance between predestination (jabr) and free will (ikhtiyār), wherein divine decree manifests through human moral accountability.

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* highlights the phrase “dabir haula’i maqtu’un” (their roots will be severed), interpreting it as the complete annihilation of moral and societal corruption embodied by Lut’s people. The specification “musbihin” (by early morning) symbolises divine judgment’s inevitability – just as dawn inevitably dispels darkness, divine justice eradicates entrenched iniquity once the parameters of guidance (hidayah) and warning (indhar) are fulfilled. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that divine punishment follows exhaustive prophetic admonition, reflecting God’s mercy even in retribution.

Significantly, Shia exegesis often links such narratives to the broader concept of wilayah (divinely ordained authority). Just as Lut’s community faced destruction for rejecting their prophet, later communities are accountable for recognising the divinely appointed Imams from the Ahl al-Bayt. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, notes that the “severed roots” metaphor applies to all who uproot the foundations of divine guidance through persistent disobedience. Jurisprudentially, this underscores the Shia view that adherence to the prophetic legacy and Imamic teachings safeguards societal morality, preventing collective divine wrath.

The verse also reinforces the Shia understanding of prophetic infallibility (‘ismah), as Lut’s unwavering conveyance of God’s command – despite personal risk – exemplifies the prophetic ideal. In this, Shia theology distinguishes between the transient fate of disbelieving communities and the eternal preservation of truth through divinely protected leaders, a theme recurrent in Shia eschatology and ethics. Thus, the verse serves as both historical account and enduring moral paradigm, intertwining divine sovereignty with human moral responsibility.
66.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr, verse 66, Allah’s decree to Prophet Lut—that the corrupt would be “eliminated by early morning”—resonates with timeless themes of divine justice and societal accountability. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Sayyed Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, emphasize that this verse transcends its historical context, serving as a metaphor for the inevitable collapse of systems built on oppression and moral decay. The “early morning” symbolizes both the abruptness of divine intervention and the clarity that follows darkness, urging societies to confront ethical rot before it consumes them.

Modern interpretations often link this narrative to current global crises. Environmental degradation, for instance, mirrors the self-destructive behavior of Lut’s people; climate scientists warn that unchecked exploitation of nature leads to collapse, much like the geological upheaval that tradition associates with Sodom’s fate. Socially, the verse critiques systemic injustices—economic inequality, political corruption, and cultural apathy—as forms of collective “sin” that destabilize communities. Scholar Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi notes that Shia theology frames such crises as calls to revive the ethical vision of the Ahlul Bayt, emphasizing communal responsibility (amr bil ma’ruf) to foster justice and sustainability.

Interfaith dialogues enrich this perspective. Jewish and Christian traditions also reflect on Sodom’s story to highlight hospitality and moral integrity, values shared across Abrahamic faiths. Philosophically, the verse challenges modern relativism; as philosopher Abdolkarim Soroush argues, ethical frameworks must balance cultural diversity with universal principles to avoid societal fragmentation.

In a multicultural world, this verse invites reflection on how moral complacency—whether in ignoring poverty, environmental abuse, or authoritarianism—risks collective consequences. The dawn of “elimination” becomes a metaphor for renewal, urging proactive transformation. For Shia communities, this aligns with Imam Ali’s teachings: justice is not passive but requires courageous engagement, echoing across today’s struggles for human dignity and ecological balance.
66.layer4:
In Surah al-Hijr, verse 66, Allah’s decisive command to Prophet Lut (AS) to uproot corruption “by early morning” carries profound spiritual lessons illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (AS). The verse exemplifies divine justice, the inevitability of accountability, and the urgency of heeding heavenly warnings—themes deeply rooted in Shia spirituality. Imam Ali (AS) taught, “Allah gives respite but does not neglect,” reminding us that divine punishment, while delayed, arrives suddenly upon those who persistently reject truth. The “early morning” here symbolizes both the abruptness of divine reckoning and the light of guidance that dispels the darkness of disbelief, a duality the Ahlul Bayt (AS) often emphasized.  

The Sixth Imam, Ja’far al-Sadiq (AS), explained that every divine decree (qada) is coupled with mercy for the believers and stern justice for the corrupt. He said, “Allah grants respite to the oppressor until, when He seizes him, He does not let him escape” (Bihar al-Anwar). This mirrors the fate of Lut’s people, who ignored repeated warnings until their “roots were severed.” The Imamah, as the延续 of divine guidance, serves as the ark of salvation in such tempests of divine wrath. The Prophet Muhammad (SAW) declared, “My Ahlul Bayt among you are like Noah’s Ark; whoever boards it is saved, and whoever abandons it drowns.” Recognizing and adhering to the Wilayah of the Imams (AS) becomes the practical means to avoid spiritual annihilation.  

Lady Fatimah (AS), in her timeless sermon, warned against prioritizing worldly attachments over divine obedience, stating, “Allah has made faith your purification from polytheism… and obedience to us [the Ahlul Bayt] a protection from disunity.” Just as Lut’s family was saved through submission to Allah’s command, our adherence to the teachings of the Imams (AS) shields us from moral and spiritual collapse.  

Practically, this verse urges believers to embrace daily renewal of faith. Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) taught in Sahifa Sajjadiyyah: “O Allah, bless me with a morning where I do not disobey You.” Spiritual vigilance—through pre-dawn prayers, reflection on Quranic warnings, and conscious adherence to the Ahlul Bayt’s ethics—anchors the soul against the storms of heedlessness. Let every sunrise remind us that divine justice, though patient, is certain, and only through the Nur (light) of the Imams (AS) can we navigate the darkness of this age.

سورہ الہجر آیت 66 میں ، اللہ نے نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم سے خطاب کیا ، اور اسے الہی فرمان سے یقین دلایا کہ وہ صبح تک اپنے کافر والے لوگوں کو تباہ کردے۔ آیت میں اس جملے کا استعمال کیا گیا ہے * "وا قادینا الیاہی دھیلیکا الامر" * ("ہم نے اسے اس معاملے کو پہنچایا") ، نتائج اور اپنے نبیوں کے ساتھ اس کے براہ راست رابطے کا فیصلہ کرنے میں اللہ کے اختیار پر زور دیتے ہوئے۔ اصطلاح * قادیانا * (ہم نے حکم دیا ہے) حتمی شکل کی عکاسی کرتا ہے ، جس سے یہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے کہ جب بدعنوانی تمام حدود سے تجاوز کر جاتی ہے تو خدائی فیصلہ ناگزیر ہوتا ہے۔ لفظ * دبیر * سے مراد کسی چیز کے "جڑ" یا "آخری بقیہ" ہے ، جو گنہگار برادری کے مکمل خاتمے کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے۔ وقت کی وضاحت -* مسبیہینا* (صبح سویرے) - الہی سزا کی اچانک اور اللہ کے منصوبے کی صحت سے متعلق دونوں کی روشنی۔

تاریخی طور پر ، اس آیت کا تعلق سدوم میں لوٹ کے لوگوں سے ہے ، جنہوں نے ان کے غیر اخلاقی طریقوں کو ترک کرنے کی اپنی کالوں کو مسترد کردیا ، جس میں وسیع پیمانے پر ناانصافی اور ہم جنس پرستی شامل ہے۔ اللہ کی انتباہ کے ذریعہ انتباہ - اور اس کی حتمی تکمیل - واضح رہنمائی کے باوجود مستقل غلط کاموں کے نتائج کے بارے میں ایک سبق کے طور پر پیش کرتا ہے۔ اس جملے * "ان گنہگاروں کو ختم کردیا جائے گا"۔

جدید مسلمانوں کے ل this ، یہ آیت تین اہم اصولوں کو تقویت دیتی ہے: اللہ کے حتمی انصاف پر اعتماد ، پیشن گوئی کی انتباہات (چاہے وہ آج کل صحیفہ یا نیک آوازوں کے ذریعے) پر عمل کرنے کی اہمیت ، اور اخلاقی حدود کو اجتماعی طور پر برقرار رکھنے کی عجلت۔ یہ ہمیں یاد دلاتا ہے کہ معاشرتی بدعنوانی ، جب معمول اور غیر جانچ پڑتال کی جاتی ہے تو ، روحانی اور مادی کے خاتمے کی دعوت دیتا ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، اس میں نظامی ظلم و ستم کی فعال طور پر مخالفت کرنے ، اخلاقی اصولوں کو حکمت کے ساتھ فروغ دینے ، اور امید کو برقرار رکھنے کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے کہ اگر چیلنجز برقرار رہیں تو بھی سچائی غالب آجائے گی۔ ڈان (*مسبیہینا*) غفلت کے اندھیرے اور خدائی مداخلت کی روشنی دونوں کی علامت ہے۔

سورہ الہجر (15:66) کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، کلاسیکی شیعہ مبصرین الہی فرمان (قادی) کی آنٹولوجیکل اتھارٹی اور شیعہ الہیات کے مرکزی الہی انصاف کے اخلاقی فریم ورک پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ آیت کے جملے - "ہم نے اسے [lut] تک پہنچایا: اس سے اہمیت: یہ کہ ان [گنہگاروں] کو صبح سویرے ختم کردیا جائے گا"۔ جیسا کہ تبتابائی *المزان *میں واضح کرتا ہے ، اصطلاح "قادینا" (ہم نے حکم دیا ہے) ایک اٹل الہی قرارداد کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جو خدا کے پہلے سے پہلے کے علم (‘ILM AL-GHAYB) سے لازم و ملزوم ہے ، جو پھر بھی تخلیق کے فریم ورک کے اندر عارضی وجہ کے ذریعے نافذ کیا گیا ہے۔ یہ پیش گوئی (JABR) اور آزاد مرضی (Ikhtiyor) کے مابین شیعہ نظریاتی توازن کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے ، جس میں الہی فرمان انسانی اخلاقی احتساب کے ذریعہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے۔

تبریسی کے * مجس البیان * نے "دبیر ہاولائی میکٹوون" کے فقرے کو اجاگر کیا ہے (ان کی جڑیں منقطع ہوجائیں گی) ، جس کی ترجمانی اس کی ترجمانی اخلاقی اور معاشرتی بدعنوانی کی مکمل فنا کے طور پر کی گئی ہے۔ "مسبیہین" (صبح سویرے تک) خدائی فیصلے کی ناگزیر ہونے کی علامت ہے - جس طرح ڈان لامحالہ اندھیرے کو دور کرتا ہے ، ایک بار رہنمائی کے پیرامیٹرز (ہیڈیہ) اور انتباہ (اندھار) کے پورا ہونے کے بعد خدائی انصاف کو ختم کردیا جاتا ہے۔ یہ شیعہ مذہبی اصول کے مطابق ہے کہ الہی سزا مکمل پیشن گوئی کی نصیحت کی پیروی کرتی ہے ، جو بدلہ میں بھی خدا کی رحمت کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔

اہم بات یہ ہے کہ ، شیعہ استثنیٰ اکثر اس طرح کے بیانیے کو ولایہ (خدائی طور پر مقرر اتھارٹی) کے وسیع تر تصور سے جوڑتا ہے۔ جس طرح لوٹ کی برادری کو اپنے نبی کو مسترد کرنے کے لئے تباہی کا سامنا کرنا پڑا ، اسی طرح بعد کی جماعتیں اے ایچ ایل البیٹ سے الہی مقرر کردہ اماموں کو پہچاننے کے لئے جوابدہ ہیں۔ امام جعفر السادق ، جیسا کہ کلاسیکی ذرائع میں حوالہ دیا گیا ہے ، نوٹ کرتا ہے کہ "کٹے ہوئے جڑیں" استعارہ ان تمام لوگوں پر لاگو ہوتا ہے جو مستقل نافرمانی کے ذریعہ الہی رہنمائی کی بنیادوں کو جڑ سے اکھاڑ دیتے ہیں۔ فقہی طور پر ، یہ شیعہ کے نظریہ کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے کہ پیشن گوئی کی میراث اور امامک تعلیمات پر عمل پیرا ہے ، معاشرتی اخلاقیات کی حفاظت کرتا ہے ، جس سے اجتماعی الہی قہر کو روکتا ہے۔

اس آیت نے پیشن گوئی کی عدم استحکام (‘عثما) کے بارے میں شیعہ کی تفہیم کو بھی تقویت بخشی ہے ، کیونکہ ذاتی خطرہ کے باوجود - خدا کے حکم کی اٹل رسالت - پیشن گوئی کے مثالی کی مثال ہے۔ اس میں ، شیعہ الہیات کافر معاشروں کی عارضی تقدیر اور خدائی محفوظ رہنماؤں کے ذریعہ سچائی کے دائمی تحفظ کے درمیان فرق کرتا ہے ، جو شیعہ اسکیٹولوجی اور اخلاقیات میں ایک مرکزی خیال ہے۔ اس طرح ، آیت تاریخی اکاؤنٹ اور پائیدار اخلاقی تمثیل دونوں کے طور پر کام کرتی ہے ، جو انسانی اخلاقی ذمہ داری کے ساتھ الہی خودمختاری کو جوڑتی ہے۔

66.layer5:
The verse in question (15:66) concludes the narrative of Prophet Lot’s people, emphasizing divine retribution against persistent wrongdoing. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly agree on the verse’s literal meaning: Allah’s decree to destroy the sinful community by dawn. Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia) concur that *“dabir”* (lit. “end” or “last part”) here signifies total annihilation, with Al-Mizan noting this reflects divine justice for moral corruption, while Tabari links it to Quranic warnings against rejecting prophets.  

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir and Qurtubi focus on the historical-legal dimensions, interpreting *“musbihin”* (early morning) as a specific temporal sign of divine power, often connecting it to Abrahamic traditions of sudden punishment. Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* frames this as a lesson in Allah’s omnipotence and the inevitability of His decree. Shia sources, particularly Al-Qummi and Tusi, extend the narrative’s symbolic resonance, with Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* highlighting the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on societal moral collapse and the necessity of divine guidance through appointed leaders.  

Theological foundations shape these nuances: Sunni exegesis often prioritizes Allah’s absolute will (*qadar*) and historical precedent, while Shia interpretations, without contradicting these principles, integrate themes of *imamah* (divinely guided leadership) and the societal consequences of rejecting truth. These differences stem from distinct hermeneutical traditions—Sunni tafsir relying heavily on prophetic hadith and companion narratives, whereas Shia works frequently incorporate the Imams’ elucidations as preserved in their tradition.  

Practically, both traditions derive ethical warnings against transgression, though Shia applications may emphasize communal responsibility under rightful guidance, while Sunni readings stress individual accountability. Such variations reflect historical developments in tafsir methodologies rather than sectarian contention, showcasing Islam’s rich interpretive diversity within a shared revelatory framework.

67.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr verse 67, Allah states: *"Wa jaa ahl al-madeenah yastabshiroon"* — "And the people of the city came rejoicing." This verse occurs within the narrative of Prophet Lut (Lot), peace be upon him, whose community in Sodom had become morally corrupt, rejecting divine guidance and indulging in forbidden acts. The "people of the city" here refer to Lut’s contemporaries who, upon hearing of the arrival of handsome strangers (actually angels sent to test them), rushed forward with sinful intentions disguised as excitement. The Arabic term *yastabshiroon* derives from *bushra*, meaning "glad tidings," but here it carries bitter irony—their "rejoicing" was rooted in heedlessness and transgression, mistaking opportunities for sin as cause for celebration.

Historically, this moment marks the climax of Lut’s community’s moral decay, illustrating how societies can normalize evil when detached from spiritual awareness. Their misplaced joy contrasts sharply with the Prophet Lut’s anguish, highlighting the tension between divine truth and collective corruption. The verse underscores a timeless lesson: not all that gladdens the heart is virtuous. Today, Muslims must discern between fleeting, worldly pleasures and lasting spiritual joy. When communities prioritize materialism, instant gratification, or unethical norms over Allah’s commands, they risk mirroring the delusion of Lut’s people. Practically, this calls for self-reflection: What do we celebrate collectively? Are our sources of happiness aligned with Quranic values? It also reminds us to uphold moral courage—like Lut, we must gently invite others to righteousness while resisting harmful social pressures. True *bushra* lies in obedience to Allah, not in chasing desires that distance us from His mercy.
67.layer2:
In *Surah Al-Hijr* (15:67), the verse *"And the people of the city came rejoicing"* marks a critical juncture in the narrative of Prophet Lut (Lot), capturing the moral and spiritual collapse of his community. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the Qur’anic context and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, emphasize the theological and ethical dimensions of this episode. As Tabrisi elucidates in *Majma al-Bayan*, the term *"yastabshirun"* (rejoicing) here carries a sinister irony: the people of Sodom approached Lut’s house not with virtuous hospitality but with predatory intent, celebrating the arrival of strangers they sought to exploit for their immoral desires. This perversion of societal norms underscores the community’s wholesale abandonment of divine guidance.  

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands on this by framing their rejoicing as a manifestation of *istikbar* (arrogance) and *istidraj* (gradual divine punishment). Their apparent "joy" reflects a deluded sense of invincibility, a hallmark of societies that persistently reject prophetic warnings. The verse thus serves as a stark reminder of the consequences of moral and spiritual degradation, a theme recurrent in Shia theology, which views societal corruption as inseparable from the rejection of God’s representatives. The Ahlul Bayt, as narrated in Shia traditions, stress that such communities inevitably face divine retribution unless they repent—a principle rooted in the Qur’anic balance between divine mercy and justice.  

The episode also connects to Shia juridical principles, particularly the obligation of *al-amr bi’l-maʿruf wa’l-nahy ʿan al-munkar* (enjoining good and forbidding evil). Prophet Lut’s struggle epitomizes the duty of divine guides to confront societal corruption, even when faced with hostility. Furthermore, Shia commentaries often link this narrative to the concept of *ghaybah* (occultation), wherein the absence of the Imam does not negate humanity’s accountability; rather, it tests the faithful’s commitment to moral vigilance.  

In essence, this verse encapsulates a timeless lesson: societies that conflate transgression with celebration risk divine annihilation, while the faithful must uphold ethical integrity as an act of devotion to the divine covenant.
67.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:67), the arrival of Lut’s people “rejoicing” captures a haunting paradox of collective moral failure masked as celebration. Contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasise that this verse underscores humanity’s tendency to normalize corruption, framing destructive behaviour as cultural pride or social progress. The “rejoicing” crowd—intent on violating Lut’s guests—symbolizes societies that weaponize unity to justify oppression, a theme echoed in modern systemic injustices, from exploitative capitalism to xenophobia. Scholar Dr. Ali Reza Rahim, in *Ethics in Quranic Narratives* (2021), links this to the psychological concept of “groupthink,” where societal conformity overrides ethical reasoning, enabling atrocities like genocide or environmental exploitation under the banner of tradition or economic growth.

Modern scientific insights into mob mentality and cognitive dissonance amplify this interpretation. Neuroscience reveals how dopamine-driven social validation can override moral instincts, explaining why communities might “rejoice” while perpetuating harm—such as celebrating industrial expansion despite climate devastation. Philosophically, the verse challenges us to interrogate collective joy: What warrants celebration? Who is excluded? This resonates with movements for racial justice, refugee rights, or LGBTQ+ dignity, where societal majority “happiness” often silences marginalised voices.

Globally, this verse critiques cultures of excess—consumerist festivals, nationalist fervour—that ignore ethical decay. It calls for *amr bil ma’ruf* (enjoining good), a Shia ethical imperative to dissent against corrupt norms. Interfaith parallels emerge in Christian critiques of Sodom’s arrogance (Ezekiel 16:49) and Buddhist teachings on *sangha* (community) accountability. Multiculturally, it invites reflection on how joy, when divorced from justice, becomes complicity. In an age of viral misinformation and polarized politics, Surah Al-Hijr 67 remains a stark reminder: true prosperity lies not in unanimous celebration, but in moral courage to question what a society deems “good.
67.layer4:
erse's depiction of a society celebrating impending sin mirrors humanity's eternal struggle between divine guidance and worldly corruption. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) teaches: *"The heart is a sanctuary – if you don’t fill it with truth, falsehood will invade it."* The rejoicing crowds in this verse expose hearts saturated with falsehood, mistaking transgression for celebration. This tragic inversion of values carries profound warnings for all generations.  

The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) emphasize that true joy flows only from proximity to Divine Will. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his progeny) said: *"The wise person places his soul under his command – he does not let it follow its desires, for the eyes of heedlessness drown the heart in darkness."* The "rejoicing" here exemplifies such heedlessness – a community intoxicated by forbidden desires, celebrating what ought to cause spiritual grief.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) illuminates this dichotomy in her historic sermon: *"You were created for immortality, yet compete for annihilation. Your hearts are distracted by worldly adornments, while your true Home awaits."* Her words transform this verse into a mirror for self-reflection: What makes *us* rejoice? Do our celebrations align with the standards of the Divine Court, or do they mirror the hollow mirth of Lut’s people?  

Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) connects such spiritual vigilance to the essence of Wilayah: *"The believer’s heart is the Throne of the Merciful – keep it worthy through obedience."* True spiritual joy arises when the heart becomes a vessel for Divine Love through adherence to the Imams’ guidance. Practical wisdom emerges here: Regularly audit your sources of happiness. Does rejoicing over wealth, status, or forbidden attractions dominate your days, or does your soul dance at the mention of Allah’s Names, the footsteps of prayer time, or acts of service guided by the Imams’ teachings?  

This verse ultimately calls believers to embrace the transformative power of Imamah – allowing the Purified Household to recalibrate their understanding of joy. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) advised: *"Train your soul through remembrance of eternity, until it finds sweetness in obedience and bitterness in sin."* Let every celebration be measured against the Scales of Hussain’s sacrifice – ensuring our laughter never comes at the cost of our connection to the Divine.

67.layer5:
The verse in question (15:67) occurs within the narrative of Prophet Lut’s community, where the people approach his house intending to harm his angelic guests. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur that the “rejoicing” (istibshār) reflects the townspeople’s immoral eagerness to commit transgressions, interpreting their apparent joy as a manifestation of moral corruption. Tabari (Sunni) and Tusi (Shia) align in viewing this as a condemnation of societal deviance, with Tabari emphasizing the historical context of divine punishment for collective sin, while Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* underscores the psychological arrogance of rejecting prophetic guidance.  

Divergences emerge in theological nuance. Shia commentaries like Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* and Qummi’s *Tafsir* often frame the narrative as a paradigm of resisting divine authority, implicitly connecting it to the ethical necessity of following infallible leadership (Ahlul Bayt). Tabatabai notes the crowd’s “rejoicing” as a willful blindness to truth, contrasting it with the spiritual vigilance taught by the Imams. Sunni scholars such as Ibn Kathir and Qurtubi, while equally condemning the people’s actions, root their analysis in broader moral accountability without explicit linkage to leadership disputes. Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* philosophically explores the irony of their misplaced joy, framing it as a failure to recognize divine warnings.  

These differences reflect distinct hermeneutical priorities: Shia tafsir frequently integrates the teachings of the Imams as interpretive authorities, whereas Sunni exegesis prioritizes prophetic traditions (hadith) and companion narratives. Historically, this stems from the Shia emphasis on the Ahlul Bayt’s role in preserving Quranic meaning post-Revelation, contrasted with Sunni reliance on the broader early scholarly consensus.  

Both traditions agree on the verse’s moral imperative against societal corruption, yet their theological frameworks shape distinct emphases—Shia readings on communal adherence to guided leadership, Sunni interpretations on individual moral vigilance—illustrating how shared scriptural foundations yield complementary ethical insights.

68.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr verse 68, Prophet Lut (Lot) addresses his people with urgency, declaring, *"Inna haula-i daifi fala tafdahuni"* (Indeed, these are my guests, so do not shame me). This plea arises as the morally corrupt people of Sodom demand access to Lut’s guests—angels sent in human form to test the community. Lut’s words highlight the sacred duty of hospitality (*dayf*) in Islam, a value deeply rooted in Abrahamic tradition. By identifying the angels as his guests, he invokes the ethical obligation to protect visitors, even amid societal pressure. The term *tafdahuni* comes from *fadiha*, meaning to disgrace or expose someone’s faults, underscoring how violating hospitality norms brings collective shame and moral failure.

Historically, this verse reflects Lut’s struggle to uphold divine principles in a society steeped in exploitation and homosexuality, which the Quran repeatedly condemns. His emphatic defense of his guests exemplifies prophetic courage—prioritizing moral integrity over communal approval. The people’s rejection of his warning ultimately leads to their destruction, illustrating the consequences of entrenched corruption.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse reinforces timeless lessons. Hospitality remains a cornerstone of Islamic ethics, requiring believers to safeguard guests and strangers, particularly the vulnerable. Beyond physical hosting, it calls for creating environments of dignity and safety in homes, mosques, and communities. Lut’s stand also models resisting societal ills—whether injustice, oppression, or immorality—with conviction, even when facing ridicule or hostility. The verse reminds us that protecting others’ honor and upholding divine laws are acts of faith, reflecting the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, who emphasized social responsibility and moral courage. By aligning our actions with these principles, we honor the legacy of the prophets and nurture a just, compassionate society.
68.layer2:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:68), Prophet Lot’s plea, *“Indeed, these are my guests, so do not shame me,”* encapsulates the ethical and theological tensions central to his prophetic mission. Classical Shia commentators, drawing from the Qur’anic narrative and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, emphasize the interplay between divine morality, societal corruption, and the prophetic duty to uphold sacred obligations.  

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, underscores the cultural and ethical weight of hospitality (*diyafa*) in ancient Semitic societies, noting that Lot’s appeal to his people reflects the sacred duty to protect guests—a principle deeply ingrained in Abrahamic tradition. The phrase *“do not shame me”* (Ar. *la tafdahuni*) conveys not merely personal embarrassment but a communal violation of trust, as Lot’s role as a host was inseparable from his prophetic responsibility to model moral integrity. Tabrisi links this to the broader Qur’anic theme of societal decay: the people’s demand to violate Lot’s guests—later revealed as angels—symbolizes their rejection of divine limits (*hudud*) and the moral inversion that justifies divine punishment.  

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands on this by framing Lot’s stand as an assertion of prophetic infallibility (*ismah*). Despite the mob’s threats, Lot’s unwavering defense of his guests exemplifies the prophets’ immunity to sin and their role as guardians of divine law. For Shia theology, this episode reaffirms the necessity of divinely appointed guides to preserve ethical order amidst societal corruption. Lot’s invocation of hospitality transcends mere custom; it becomes a theological act—defending the sanctity of divine mercy embodied in the angels’ presence.  

Jurisprudentially, this verse informs Shia ethical frameworks on guest rights (*haq al-diyafa*) and the obligation to protect the vulnerable, even at personal risk. The Ahlul Bayt’s teachings, as recorded in texts like *Al-Kafi*, tie such obligations to the broader principle of *amr bi’l-ma’ruf* (enjoining good), emphasizing that moral guardianship is integral to communal salvation. The destruction of Lot’s people thus serves as an eternal warning: societies that abandon ethical boundaries and reject divine guidance inevitably court annihilation. Through this lens, the verse becomes a microcosm of the Shia worldview—where prophetic leadership, moral courage, and divine justice converge to sustain cosmic balance.

In Surah Al-Hijr (15:68), Prophet Lot’s plea—“These are my guests; do not shame me”—resonates with timeless ethical urgency. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Mohammad Ali Taskhiri, emphasize this verse as a foundation for *dayaa* (sacred hospitality), framing it as a moral imperative to protect the vulnerable against societal oppression. The narrative transcends its historical context, speaking to modern struggles against xenophobia, displacement, and the erosion of communal ethics. Lot’s defiance of his community’s corruption—marked by aggression and the violation of guest rights—parallels today’s global refugee crises, where marginalized groups face dehumanization. Scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim highlight how the Quranic ethic of *amaanah* (trusteeship) obliges Muslims to advocate for displaced populations, reflecting Imam Ali’s teaching that “people are either your brothers in faith or equals in humanity.”

Scientific studies on social cohesion, such as Robert Putnam’s research, affirm that inclusive societies thrive by integrating newcomers, aligning with Lot’s model of prioritizing guest dignity over communal prejudice. Philosophically, the verse challenges moral relativism: ethical courage lies in resisting majority tyranny, a theme echoed in movements for racial justice and LGBTQ+ rights. Here, Shia theology distinguishes between condemning *fahsha* (transgressive acts) and upholding universal human dignity—critiquing the reduction of Sodom’s sin to a single issue rather than its systemic violence and inhospitality.

Interfaith parallels abound: Jewish midrashim and Christian parables likewise exalt hospitality, offering common ground for collaborative advocacy. In an era of polarization, Lot’s stand invites interreligious dialogue on protecting the marginalized—a shared imperative across traditions. Ultimately, this verse calls for a proactive ethics of care, urging communities to embody *rahma* (compassion) in confronting dehumanization, whether in Gaza’s rubble or Europe’s borders. As contemporary scholar Fatima Barkatullah notes, “To shame Lot’s guests is to betray the divine trust; their sanctuary is our test.
68.layer4:
In the sacred verse where Prophet Lot declares, "Indeed, these are my guests, so do not shame me," we uncover profound layers of spiritual responsibility and moral courage illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as). This moment of prophetic steadfastness reflects the divine principle of wilayah (guardianship) – the luminous chain of divinely appointed leadership entrusted to protect sacred boundaries and uphold human dignity. Imam Ali (as) taught, "The guest is a mercy from Allah; whoever accepts it has accepted Allah’s mercy." Here, Lot embodies the Imam’s teaching, transforming hospitality into an act of divine trust and resistance against corruption.

The Ahlul Bayt (as) emphasized that defending the vulnerable is inseparable from faith. Lady Fatimah (as) stated, "The pleasure of Allah lies in the pleasure of the parents, and His wrath lies in their wrath," extending the duty of care beyond familial ties to all entrusted to one’s protection. Prophet Lot’s plea mirrors the Imamah’s eternal role as guardians of spiritual and social sanctity. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) explained, "The believer is a fortress for his brother, just as walls are fortresses for cities," teaching that true faith demands active protection of others’ honor and safety.

This verse also exemplifies the Shia mandate of *Amr bil Ma’ruf* (enjoining good) and *Nahi anil Munkar* (forbidding evil). Lot’s refusal to surrender his guests to societal deviance resonates with Imam Hussain’s (as) stand at Karbala, where he shielded the essence of Islam from distortion. The Prophet Muhammad (saw) said, "Whoever among you sees evil, let him change it with his hand; if he cannot, then with his tongue; if he cannot, then with his heart – and that is the weakest of faith." Lot’s defiance illustrates the "changing with the hand" – direct, principled action against moral decay.

Practically, this invites believers to cultivate prophetic courage in daily life: welcoming strangers, defending the oppressed, and rejecting societal sins through both word and deed. It reminds us that wilayah is lived through sacred responsibility – protecting others’ dignity as an extension of love for the Ahlul Bayt (as). As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) prayed in *Sahifa Sajjadiyya*, "Make me a sanctuary for the one who seeks sanctuary in me," urging us to become living embodiments of divine refuge. Let Lot’s example inspire us to guard the "guests" in our lives – truth, justice, and the vulnerable – as acts of devotion to the luminous path of the Fourteen Infallibles.

68.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hijr 15:68, both Shia and Sunni scholars converge on the foundational ethical principle of hospitality (ḍiyāfa) as a sacred duty. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) in their respective tafsirs emphasize Prophet Lot’s urgent plea to his people as a defense of guest rights, rooted in Abrahamic tradition. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tabarsi both contextualize the verse within the broader narrative of Lot’s community’s moral corruption, agreeing that the prophet’s appeal underscores the inviolability of protecting guests—a virtue repeatedly commended in Quranic ethics. Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) further align in viewing Lot’s statement as a rhetorical strategy to awaken his people’s conscience by appealing to their cultural norms of honor.

Divergences emerge in theological emphases. Shia commentaries like Al-Mizan by Tabatabai and Tafsir al-Qummi often highlight Lot’s role as a moral guide resisting societal corruption, drawing parallels to the Imams’ struggles against injustice. These works stress the interplay between divine guidance (hidaya) and human responsibility, reflecting the Shia theological focus on divinely appointed leadership. Sunni exegetes such as Al-Razi and Al-Qurtubi prioritize the literal narrative, with Al-Razi’s Mafatih al-Ghayb analyzing the psychological dynamics of shame (fadiha) as a deterrent to sin, reflecting the Sunni emphasis on communal morality and individual accountability.

While both traditions reinforce hospitality as a religious duty, Shia interpretations may inspire emulation of prophetic and Imamic steadfastness, whereas Sunni readings often emphasize adherence to prophetic precedent (sunnah) as a communal obligation. Historically, these differences stem from distinct hermeneutical frameworks: Shia tafsir integrates the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt as interpretive authorities, while Sunni scholarship prioritizes transmitted narrations (riwayat) from the Prophet’s companions. Both approaches, however, uphold the verse’s core message: the ethical imperative to protect the vulnerable against societal transgressions.

69.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hijr (15:69), the Prophet Lut (Lot) addresses his people as they threaten to violate his guests—a group sent by Allah, including angels in human form. The verse captures his urgent plea: *“Wattaqullah wa la tukhzuun”* (“And fear Allah and do not disgrace me”). This cry emerges from a pivotal moment when Lut’s community, entrenched in immoral practices, seeks to humiliate him by harming his guests—a grave breach of Arab cultural and Islamic ethics that sanctified hospitality. Lut ties their moral failure to two principles: *taqwa* (conscious fear of Allah) and avoiding *ikhza’* (disgrace), urging them to recognise both divine accountability and the social duty to uphold dignity.  

The term *taqwa* conveys a shield against sin through God-consciousness, while *tukhzuun* (from *khaziya*, “to disgrace”) implies public shame for violating sacred trusts. Lut’s dual appeal transcends his immediate crisis, stressing that immorality dishonours both Allah and His messengers. Classical scholars like Allamah Tabatabai note this verse underscores Islam’s integration of spiritual and social responsibility—transgressions harm individuals *and* communities.  

For modern Muslims, this verse speaks to upholding ethical integrity amid societal pressures. It condemns complicity in injustice, reminding believers that protecting the vulnerable (like guests, refugees, or marginalised groups) is tied to divine duty. Practically, it calls for resisting actions that “disgrace” our faith—whether through hypocrisy, harming others, or neglecting communal rights. Just as Lut defended his guests against exploitation, Muslims today must safeguard dignity in their relationships, advocating for justice and hospitality as expressions of *taqwa*. The verse thus becomes a timeless mandate: live in awe of Allah, and let that reverence manifest as moral courage.
69.layer2:
In Surah al-Hijr (15:69), the plea of Prophet Lut (a) to his people, *"And fear Allah and do not disgrace me,"* encapsulates a profound theological and ethical duality central to Shia exegesis. Classical commentators emphasize the interconnectedness of *taqwa* (God-consciousness) and the moral responsibility toward divine representatives, reflecting the inseparability of faith and adherence to prophetic guidance in Shia thought. 

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, interprets the verse as addressing both the immediate context of Lut’s people threatening his guests and the broader principle of safeguarding prophetic honor. He notes that disgracing a prophet transcends personal insult; it constitutes a rejection of divine authority, as prophets are manifestations of Allah’s *hujjah* (proof) over creation. The disgrace here lies not merely in violating hospitality—a grave moral failing—but in undermining the sanctity of prophethood itself, a theme recurrent in Shia theology, which views the protection of divine guides as a communal obligation.

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands on this by linking the verse to the concept of *ismah* (prophetic infallibility). The appeal *"do not disgrace me"* underscores the societal duty to uphold the dignity of divinely appointed leaders, as their humiliation reflects a collective failure in recognizing spiritual authority. This aligns with the Shia understanding of *wilayah* (guardianship), wherein respect for the Prophet (s) and the Ahl al-Bayt (a) is inseparable from obedience to Allah. Tabatabai further observes that the dual command—fearing Allah and avoiding disgrace—highlights how moral and spiritual corruption (here, the intended sin of Lut’s people) stems from abandoning *taqwa*, which inevitably leads to societal decadence.

The verse also resonates with Shia jurisprudence, where hospitality and protection of the vulnerable are sacred duties. Violating these, as Lut’s people intended, constitutes both a legal and spiritual transgression. Classical scholars like Shaykh al-Tusi contextualize such ethical breaches as symptoms of rejecting *tawhid* (divine unity), as moral decay and disrespect for divine guides fracture the covenant between Creator and creation. Thus, the verse serves as a timeless admonition: upholding divine law and honoring those who embody it are inextricable acts of faith.

Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, interpret this verse as a timeless call to uphold both personal *taqwa* (God-consciousness) and communal dignity. The “disgrace” Ibrahim fears isn’t merely personal shame but the tarnishing of prophetic mission—a reminder that individual actions ripple outward, affecting collective spiritual and ethical integrity.
